This game was good - at the time of CIV IV. Now it is just a shadow of its former self. The update policy can only be described as a disaster. The Linux version (like the Mac version) lags significantly behind the Windows version and according to support, [b}there are currently no plans to change that[/b]. But even with the latter, not everything works as advertised. These challenges, which were announced with great fanfare, are still unplayable for me because the corresponding menu item is still not available after 3 months - ridiculous ...

This game is a lot of fun! From the strategic and exciting gameplay to the very expressive facial animations and voice acting. Sean Bean does not die here so that is also a good thing for the game. A great game and I recommend this a lot. Good fun alone and when playing with friends. The amount of leaders and nations in the game is impressive as well.

The Steam version of this game is buggy and requires constant reinstalls and reconfiguration. In retrospect I wish I had tried a different platform for this game. But hey! It's 90% off now. If I had gotten it for that price, maybe I wouldn't be complaining.

2024 update: Still not playable across 3 different systems.

This game is a masterpiece of strategy and history, where I can create my own civilization and lead it through the ages. The game has amazing graphics, sound, and music that immerse me in the world. The game also has a lot of depth and variety, with different leaders, civilizations, units, wonders, districts, policies, and more. The game also has a great multiplayer mode, where I can compete or cooperate with other players online.

However, the game also has some drawbacks that prevent it from being perfect. The game is very complex and can be overwhelming for new players, especially with the lack of a proper tutorial. The game can also be very long and slow, especially in the late game, where turns can take forever. The game can also be very frustrating, as the AI is often irrational and aggressive, and the diplomacy system is lacking and inconsistent. The game can also be buggy and unstable, especially after updates and expansions.

Overall, I think this game is one of the best 4X strategy games ever made, but it also has some flaws that need to be addressed. I would recommend this game to anyone who loves strategy and history, but also has a lot of patience and time.

An enjoyable entry in the Sid Meier's Civilization franchise. The artstyle is a bit cartoony but it fits with the rest of the graphic world design and so does not stick out. The gameplay is simple while still offering a decently high skill ceiling. 
The most blatant negative is that 80% of the game's content, certainly some of the most fun mechanics, is locked behind DLCs that are not exactly pocket change.

I have played civ since civ#2 and have found different things to enjoy about all of them. Civ VI has a wide variety of aspects to learn and can get very complex if you desire true greatness. They have done an excellent job at creating the game for beginners and experts alike. 
Like everyone will, I have my own ideas and opinions on how the game experience could improve. It is up to you to play and experience these things on your own. Expand and explore to new lands never before seen. Meet new leaders (players) and choose in which way you will lead your people to your utopia regardless of the challenges that lay ahead.
It is difficult to see myself ever stop being a Civilization player. I am addicted, and do not wish to stop.

I've played Civ since I was a teenager in the early 2000s and have always upgraded to the newest release.  This game is great and a lot of fun to play if strategy turn based games are your cup of tea; they're not for everyone.  I am conflicted between Civ VI and Civ V; Civ VI was a big reach in the sense that a LOT changed from the regular game everyone was used to since the initial release.  Although gameplay is a bit different, mostly because the focus seemed to be on a new feel for the graphics and overall look of the game, it is still just as fun as playing Civ V.  Highly recommended to anyone that likes these types of games.

I've been a civ 5 player for years, and never felt the need to switch over to 6. However, after being encouraged by a buddy to try it out again, I am enjoying Civ 6 quite a lot!  The updates made over the last couple years (especially the heroes mode in the Babylon pack.. super dope) have made the game much more enjoyable to play, and, with just a couple mods, the game becomes even more wonderful. I don't recommend playing this game if you have responsibilities, as they will lose priority to the addiction of crumbling your enemies' empires to dust. Aside from that, no complaints!

4/4.20

I've given this game a chance multiple times but I can't seem to recommend Civ 6. 

For the record, I am a huge fan of Civ 5 and I've been trying to adapt my game sense from Civ 5 to Civ 6, it just doesn't connect most of the time because the game has a lot of questionable changes from Civ 5.

TL;DR if you wanna try a Civ game, please try Civ 5 instead.

Bad things:
- Movement is heavily nerfed, where you can't inch out moves to a high cost hex if you have only 1 movement left. Previously in Civ 5, you can still cross a river if your remaining movement is 1. Mobility feels really bad now especially when surrounded or on some terrains that randomly has hills next to it, making exploration feels really bad.

- Global Happiness is changed to Amenities. Amenities are basically Local Happiness per city. The Amenity system is a huge problem mainly for expansion because the new city can't grow big without building amenity buildings and in extension, the housing system. In Civ 5, since there is a Global Happiness, you can carry the newer cities in happiness by having higher overall happiness to begin with, so they grow without any halt, making the newer cities not so much of a burden than it is worth. With the Amenity system AND the Housing system in Civ 6, obviously, the newer cities are basically a burden to your civilization until you decided to build amenity buildings with workers, which have its own problem.

- Workers are expendables now with charges. It doesn't make sense in any explanation. Do the workers just die after building some buildings now? Anyway, this means that you have to spare some production in your cities to build more workers now instead of other useful productions which feels very bad for the progression.

- The general UI is opaque, ugly, and hard to read sometimes. They settled with a hard opaque blue for the background of their UI, which makes it harder to read the fine details and numbers. Also, the fog of war is a novel idea being a map and all, but the brown color hinders a lot of the readability of the terrain especially if the terain itself is yellowish in color.

- Districts instead of buildings. Novel idea at best, which tries to utilize empty hexes into use. But this is where you also need to upgrade a city's amenities, housing, and also libraries, workshops, etc. "You'd have to think what you wanted to build in your city, which is good for the amount of strategy approaches you have" is what I would say if amenities and housing isn't so much of a problem to begin with.

- The Culture track is a research tree now. Only difference is that you have to apply the cultures within a card system to actually apply the culture for your civilization. It is a bad change in general. Culture track is executed better in Civ 5 with the Social Policy system where it is a selection of different cultures depending on your choices and speciality. It is understandable that Cultures need to be researched before you actually apply it in the society, but putting this in Civ 6 feels like every civilization don't have their distinct playstyle in culture. Every civilization feels like it has the same culture because you have to start with the same one because you have to research them, whereas in Civ 5, you can already start with a different tree.

- Envoys from what I heard is how you be allies with a city state, however I haven't touched that system ever, it looks unnecessarily convoluted for their own good. Civ 5's city state allying system is kinda bad because it dumbs down to spending gold on them at the end game, but it is easy to understand and straightforward. I can't seem to understand Envoys and the beginning fact that you need envoys instead of gold to befriend them is another "unnecessary currency" in my book.

- Golden Ages doesn't feel rewarding at all, I don't even know when is my Golden Age. I've reached Golden age one time but it doesn't even have any effect on my civilization. This point is just me being confused, which is also elevated due to the UI being terrible.

- Character design is a straight downgrade. They directed the designs to more cartoonish than somewhat "realistic" and "grounded". As a result, they all look ugly. Not a single character or leader in this game looks good in my opinion. The designs between characters are vastly different and incoherent they seem to not be the same species. For all I know some of the leaders could be an alien.

- The natural disaster DLC pretty much ruins the game's pacing and knowledge. Previously, settling on a flood plain / besides a river is generally a good choice because you will have access to fresh water, and that leads to more population. Now, there are disasters and flood plains can actually flood now and it destroys a city's economy just like that. That inherently teaches everyone to not build on areas that actually makes the civilization prosperous, the logic is ass-backwards.

- The hero DLC (I think it's a DLC) is also convoluted, and unrewarding to make those heroes, because they will die of natural causes after a few turns.

There are some good changes like the Wonders built occupying a hex to prevent "Wonder Racing" is good, and the multiple leaders approach of the same Civilization is great so you can pick and match which leader of that civilization is the best for your playstyle. However, as mentioned above, I can't recommend this due to the huge amount of negatives outweighing the positives.

Civilization 6 is the ultimate strategy game. Part 1 of this game has been around since 1991 and was the reason for me to buy a computer way back when. In this game you can play dozens of different leaders and nationalities. You can build world wonders like the Pyramids, the Eiffel tower or the Statue of Liberty.
It all starts off in the stone age, where you research technologies like the wheel and pottery. As you progress through the eras you go from classical times to the medievals and, after a while, way beyond to the future era. The technologies you unlock make it possible for you to build better fighting units like horsemen and archers in the beginning, to tanks and fighter jets in later eras, a s well as a host of rescourses previously invisible  on your map. A similar thing happens with culture, where you unlock new systems of government, new buildings and wonders.
You can start a religion by earning a Great Prophet. You can also recruit Great People like Albert Einstein and Rembrandt van Rijn. Each with his own unique benefits.
There are a nember of different ways to win including a war victory, a diplomatic victory and a space race victory. In the last you must be the first to settle on Mars! I reccomend you play this game against the computer. (single-Player) As the game takes a long time to finish and this may not be feasable for players in different time zones. A must-buy and crittically acclaimed classic of a video game. Enjoy!

I usually do like strategy games. And I also like board games. In the classical sense with friends sitting at a table, and probably playing over few weeks, but also on a computer.
Thing is, this game is plain boring.
I would even go so far and say that you actually do not need to make any strategic decisions, since the development is straight with no real possible iterations. There is literally no real possibility of a derivation tactics.

Probs my biggest complain: it takes like for ever and not much happens in the meantime 

The AI actions are incredible stupid - as others already pointed out. You get denounced for no reason, you get aggression for no reason, your friend starts a war for no reason etc.
Also I do not think it is that well balanced - even if it makes a first impression of being sophisticated.
To separate the culture tree from science research tree - ok, but combining free market with communism?! Sure is weird.
The different forms to win may sound appealing - as it is a derivation of what you usually get of games within this genre, but this gets demolished by the irrational behaviors of the AI and game wise through the constant need of increasing the availability of resources. 
In other words: The more science buildings, the more science points. the faster the research etc. this can be transferred to any other building tree of the four main ways to win. SO it boils down to the question of who can efficiently build the first towns and conquer enough space to be the largest empire in order to gain the greatest advantage resource wise.
So, under the bottom line, if you are dominant with your military, you are safe to win. Also concerning diplomatics btw., as you can easily influence your neighboring empires with resources to trade for diplomatic points. Plus you can easily win those challenges or wagers for aid requests if you are just a large enough empire. Or eradicate the one threatening to win if necessary ^^

As mentioned earlier on, basically in this game you have nothing to do, nothing happens - a one click thing. 

After the tutorial (which I didn't finish since it already bored me to death but maybe spend 3h in it and that is incredible long for a freaking tutorial), I had hoped for more exciting gameplay with more nations involved - so started a game. Yeah now after much over 30h played and at round 350whatish of 500max and I won with science - launching all 4 space projects in a row. But I chose this approach since it was the most appealing to find a disclosure with this game and finish one game and never go back there again.

The Short: The game has been coded to completely ignore "the rules" that the player has to abide by. The AI can simply poop out troops with complete disregard for supply/materials, and can do so endlessly. For the average casual player this means you simply can't win on play-style alone at "Prince" difficulty or above, you have to rely on sheer luck for the AI to fight each other and keep themselves from out-developing you. Mods to try and level the playing field (without simply using cheat mods that make you invincible) are worthless, as the AI can manufacture top-level (or always one or two levels above yours) regardless of their tech level or materials available.

For reference, I used to LOVE this game. I think I picked up my first Civ game around Civ 3 and enjoyed all of them up to this one. Civ 6 PRIOR to the Gathering Storm DLC was very playable, but the Devs seem to now require a Master's Degree in Civ-ology just to play against the AI, and don't even bother with the older Civs as they are almost across the board complete crap vs the newer Civs/Leaders. 

if you watch enough Vids on Leader/Civ "rankings" you will not find an older/original Civ in the top. Virtually all of them reside at average or below. So forget about playing your favorite/home Civ. Most amazingly, the strongest (historically) Civilization on the planet is one of the weakest.

The game is simply not for the casual player who wants to sit down and play the game after a crap-tastic day at work .. it will only add to your frustration .. lol. Though you can play at a lower difficulty level and on "Standard" rules the AI still cheats it's fanny off to win. The game is simply a dumpster-fire of coded slop.

This game so far, 82 hours in, is incredibly fun & addictive. If you're interested in history through the eras, the warfare around said history, famous figures, - or if you'd enjoy a game that mixes elements of classic tabletops like Risk with modern RTS video game aspects (such as turn-based combat, attrition/expansion elements, base building & management, negotiations, enduring & drawn-out conflicts... etc.), then Civ 6 will satisfy you, trust me.
I grew up on games like C&C, Halo Wars, and Supcom, and also love non-combat city builders like Sim City or Cities Skylines, but never found a game that combined the two in a presentable form until playing this, and Civ 5. You claim a capital for your nation, expand as quickly & efficiently as you can, tech-up through the eras until you eventually claim victory - which itself can be achieved in a variety of ways... religious domination, cultural popularity domination, and good old fashioned brutish conquest are just three ways in the vanilla game. Not to mention that you develop friendships or rivalries with other nations along the way, start to finish, and these relationships can and will impact your odds of coming out on top if you don't play your cards right.
Aside from that blurb, it comes with mod support, a decent map editor, access to the Steam workshop (tons more maps if you aren't familiar with the editor, or mods to spice things up), and in terms of hardware requirements... well, I play on an Asus, which can't run Ark Ascended or BF2042 on lowest settings - but it can run just about anything else I've played besides those two and others like without mah boi having a stroke - and Civ 6 on max settings even with additions to graphics through mods runs without any issues.

Case point: It's a very fun, addicting, and well-polished game. It is always on sale it seems, and the base price isn't very unreasonable for what you get out of it. Not having any of the DLC's isn't going to severely negatively impact your experience, BUT having them does add a ton more content to enjoy. If I were you, I'd give it a spin if it's on sale or something, odds are you will like it.

gaem

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

A classic strategy game, it is a must-have for anyone interested in history and societies. Seeing your fledgling little one-city tribe prosper to become a world power is just fun.

The main issue is that the existing game simply feels under-designed. In particular the Civic system is completely under-developed and both Civic and Tech trees are much too sparse. Fortunately, we have mods to fix most of these issues. Unfortunately the systems underlying supporting those mods has become glitchy and unstable. This has rendered the game nigh unplayable in any enjoyable version.

EDIT--16-Feb.-2024---At some point updates have made this game fairly unplayable when mixing in interesting (i.e., necessary) mods. It is forever crashing or failing to properly load mods. My hope for Civ 7 is that much, much, much, much, much, much more robust mod support alongside much, much, much, much, much, much more transparent and easily findable logs. It's really not clear to me what causes crashes. Beyond a possibility that it's something to do with assets...which are capped at a monumentally small amount. Civ 7, needs to support out of the box 4~5 times the assets it actually comes with in order to facilitate access by the mod community. Support for 20,000+ assets is a must. 

So still not recommended. Ultimately, while Civ V remains somewhat better than Civ VI, I do believe the true height of this game with respect to optimal and robust functionality (and lack of crashes) was Civ IV. Which is pretty sad.

So much potential... I've been a fan of the civilization series since the 90s, and played endless hours of Civ 2,3,4, and 5, and all the expansions. Looking at Civ 6 on paper, it sounds great. Civic policy tree separate from tech tree? That's good. Better espionage system? Check. Ability to switch government types? That's a good change. So what went wrong? Why did I play it some and then end up going back to Civ 5?

Overly-scripted and over-prescribed requirements for city districts and wonders. The idea of unstacking the city is not a bad one, in theory. But with all the adjacency bonuses, it becomes too much of a hassle. And then the wonders- since when does the statue of zeus take up an entire tile?! You should be able to built it in your city center, or in another district. But instead each wonder has a host of adjacency requirements. "Must be built adjacent to a river, adjacent to city center, adjacent to a science district, and on hilly desert terrain"... come on. All this takes away from the fun organic nature of civ that was a hallmark since the beginning.

Additionally - the AI has some major issues. It is incompetent. I find it annoyingly easy to take out, and it seems to have no clue how to build an army, upgrade it, and conduct a large-scale war. I even downloaded some mods and they still suck at war. 

Finally, the graphics are too cartoonish for me. I downloaded mods for that, too... but it didn't help enough. I've gone back and played Civ 5 and I'm happy with that.

A Timeless Masterpiece That Redefines Addictive Gaming

Civilization VI stands as a testament to the enduring brilliance of the strategy genre, offering a gaming experience that transcends time. It is, without a doubt, one of the most addicting games I've ever played, delivering a complete and unparalleled masterpiece that captivates from start to finish.

The Good:

Addictive Gameplay: Civilization VI excels in creating a gaming experience that is both challenging and addictive. The "just one more turn" mantra is a testament to the game's ability to keep players engrossed for hours on end. The depth of strategy and the constant pursuit of victory make every playthrough a unique and compelling journey.

Strategic Depth: The game's strategic depth is staggering. From choosing your civilization to managing city development, diplomacy, and warfare, every decision feels consequential. The interplay of various game mechanics ensures that players must adapt and strategize to thrive, providing a rich and satisfying experience.

Beautifully Crafted World: Civilization VI boasts a visually stunning world with vibrant and detailed graphics. The diverse landscapes, iconic wonders, and animated units contribute to the overall immersion, bringing the historical civilizations to life in a way that is both educational and visually pleasing.

Expansive Content: The game's expansions and DLCs have consistently added significant content, enhancing the depth and variety of gameplay. From new civilizations and leaders to additional game mechanics, the ongoing support from the developers ensures that the Civilization VI experience continues to evolve and remain fresh.

The Not-So-Good:

Diplomatic Inconsistencies: The diplomatic behavior of AI civilizations can sometimes be inconsistent or illogical. Players may encounter situations where AI leaders make decisions that seem contrary to their established personality traits or the current global context.

Conclusion:

Civilization VI is not just a game; it's a masterpiece that defines the pinnacle of addictive gaming. Its addictive nature stems from the perfect blend of strategic depth, engaging gameplay, and an ever-expanding world of possibilities. Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a timeless gem that has set the standard for the 4X strategy genre, and its enduring appeal ensures that it will continue to captivate gamers for generations to come.

1. big number go up = very satisfying. The gameplay is relatively simple, in that increasing yields, both on tiles and empire wide is the go-to strategy
2. districts are a fairly simple, easy-to-grasp concept, which set a much more defined course than the endless improvements in Civ V
3. three differend gamesets / DLCs allow you to pick the gamerules you like best. Don't like the pesky climate change? Pick the base game. Do you like governors and loyalty? Pick GS or the other DLC
4. basically endless replayability due to a large number of Civs with alternate leaders and randomly generated maps
5. incredible amount of mods that allow you to customize the game however the hell you like it best
6. very chill, relaxed game you don't need to think too hard about
7. to each their own; there's a suitable Civ for ever player

Cons:
1. the launcher
2. the rather dissapointing extra content (scenarios and exclusively multiplayer gamemodes like Red Dead and Pirates)
3. said game modes also last a limited amount of turns, giving you too little time to get into it
4. kind of hard to learn / a little bit intimidating
5. AI is bad, so incredibly incompetent that higher difficulties entail giving the AI huge boosts to its yields without improving their district placement, wartime strategy, production priorities, etc
6. you do need a pretty powerful PC to handle larger map sizes (anything above standard - large)

I've played every Civilization game since the first came out, spent way too many hours on the franchise during the years, but I'm done with this one. Lots of people love the game based on the continued activity around it, but for me, the game has a constant barrage of events and happenings of questionable value to the game, leading to a feeling that I'm working against a game rather than running my civilization. There's a lot to learn in this game and the rewards aren't there, I feel distracted all the time with all the different aspects to manage. To make it worse, the UI isn't the best, the controls are sometimes not obvious, it's hard to get an overview of what's going on and I don't like the more cartoony style the graphics has taken.

One thing to note is that the best game is pretty limited and one needs to get the DLCs to get the complete experience, which means watching out for a sale if one doesn't want to pay through the nose. Essentially requiring DLCs is also not an endorsement of the game.

I always come back to the franchise. Its one of my favorite games to play in between serious RPGs. I honestly love playing as a different leader on huge maps to create unique situations and how i can implement different research and civic strategies.

The only good thing about this game is the music. The bad things are many:

* The graphics are cartoonish.
* The AI does not know how to play the game. It often declares war and then does not send any soldier to the attacked country. This game has many adjacency-based bonuses that the AI usually ignores completely. Higher difficulty levels give bonuses to the AI, but do not make it any less dumb.
* When either the player or the AI launches an invasion, units more often than not become obsolete due to scientific research before they arrive.
* At the start of the game, there is little to do. In the endgame, there is an enormous amount of micromanagement to do and it hardly matters.
* There is enormous â€œsnowballingâ€ (as it is called in the civ fanatics forums). I.e.: The more of an advantage you have over your enemies, the faster such advantage grows. This is present in almost all strategy games. However, in this game it is especially nefarious because of many multiplicative bonuses.
* Development of this game (DLCs) adds additional content, but does not fix the already broken dynamics.

Overall, the biggest flaw of this game is that there is far more micromanagement than strategy. Paradox Risk-like strategy games are simply better games than this, as they do not have that flaw.

JUST ONE MORE TURN

Prior Civ experience: Civ, Civ II & Civ III.  Stayed with Civ III forever because I found the subsequent emphasis on graphics annoying, cartoonish and resource hungry.  So I didn't give IV or V much of a chance.

I have played the Civ VI tutorial for a few hours and one game as Scythia to turn 200 so far.  I tend to be an empire builder with a focus on commerce and military.  I am a methodical planner.

1. The fact that the tutorial won't allow saves is ridiculous.  In prior versions, thoughtfully and slowly working through the various game stages from the tutorial was an excellent way to learn.  The Civ VI tutorial was really limited and I found the constant chatter annoying.  What I needed/wanted was explanations and the future implications of various choices.  Too much animation and audio and not enough detailed text to read.

2. The number of available civilizations to choose from is too small, and labeling them by leader rather than the name of the civilization is counter intuitive.  The game is called Civ, not Leader.  Most well known civilizations had multiple great leaders.

3. The complexity and nuances of separate tech and civic trees with policies is terrific and a vast improvement over the original Civ games - HOWEVER, the tutorial and in-game information about this stuff is severely limited.  It's annoying that I need to continually research using third party material.

4. Two days in, and it's clear that a handful of mods are not just a good idea, but necessary for those players who enjoy the long game.  The 50 move get it over with crowd might not care, but I really don't enjoy getting dozens of hours into a game only to discover that there are severe penalties for not knowing the subtleties of where to place city improvements, for example.  I'm not certain yet, but it seems as if we've gone back to the Civ II concept of specific trading between cities that rely on geographic and improvement differences between cities.  IE, an urban engine fed by rural farmers.

5. I remain confused about cursor control. I'm not used to accidentally sending units to the wrong tiles. Sometimes right click releases the cursor focus and sometimes it sends a unit.  Sometimes the escape key gets me back to the standard game view and sometimes it pulls up the game menu.  Sometimes I can't figure out how to make a screen or pop up go away - like the search tool. In short, the interface is busy, confusing and inconsistent.  I'm used to left click = focus, right click = select an option & esc = reset to basic game screen.

6. The "turn end/next turn" button flashes when I have units who haven't moved and who are not fortified or sleeping.  I don't understand this.  I'm wasting time "visiting" units to check on their movement capacity. 

7. Not certain what I think about the limitation against unit stacking and the ability for foreign units to pass right through another civ's units. It certainly changes tactics massively and was not explained in the tutorial.

8. Graphics and animations are too cartoonish.  Would love the option to tone all that down.  Builders jumping up and down and vanishing in an explosion?  I'm not six years old. It's silly and childish.   

9. Was several turns into first game before I discovered that land units could be directed across water (as if by magic, boats appear).  This is bizarre.  Here I was, methodically researching and building harbors and ships when I could have expanded to other continents already.  I don't see how this makes any sense, or how this is an improvement over the prior need to plan and organize the ability to move across large bodies of water.

10. A dialogue box asking what you want to do with a defeated barbarian outpost would be useful. Hidden somewhere is an icon that needs to be pressed to totally destroy them - I didn't know that, and they became a city state later, despite my having vanquished them early on.  Annoying as hell.  Just so many things that you have to learn through trial and error, and for those of us who actually like to RTFM, it's horrible.

11. Religion.  Sigh... there is a REAL emphasis on this and limited in-game information.  Having started on a small, 4 civ game I discovered too late that all the prophets had been snatched up and another civ had built Stonehenge.  I'm not certain, but it appears as if even if religion is not your thing, you need to found one to prevent other civs from unduly impacting you and possibly winning the game in that manner.  The idea that some other civ has units wandering my lands proselytizing fantasies and I can't do much about it is annoying.  I'd like the ability to capture those units, load them into a siege engine and hurl their corpses back across the border.

Despite all these bitches (and I have more), I am intrigued by the complexities and nuances of the tech/civic/policy construct and think Civ6 is worth investing some time in to get over what appears to be a MASSIVE learning curve.

The best thing about the game for me is that you can leave it running and still play it while doing something else (writing a letter/memo, etc). Over the years I have played 22714 hours (as of this writing) and I always play alone (never online) and usually choose a different character as well as changing the parameters for each game. It is the game I play most. I think I bought the CD when it first came out (before steam).

Even when the word on everyone's lips is AI integration into every aspect of real life, developers are stuck in 1999 and cannot  be bothered to deliver "ai" opponents that actually play better as you increase difficulty but, still, cheat more. if you play king or above difficulty you have no choice but be aggressive, capture settlers, capture capital cities, at least with your closest 2 neighbors, otherwise you're left far behind. Their settles, workers, wonders, all produce faster, sometimes 2 at the same time with no money in inventory...

likes:
wonders take up hexes. I'm whoring for wonders in every game, and in civ 5 you can put them all in you capital for maximum culture boost. here you have to make your choices for they take up space.

dislikes:
districts. they're not cheap, you have to think carefully where you put them, and really, do I need 2 districts for a library and a workshop?! also, playing maps with small islands is no longer doable due to districts.
charges mechanics on workers
ages are meh. golden age is easy to get and does not deliver on the name.
and I cannot stress this enough, dumb cheating ai. there is no difficulty setting that gives you a challenge but also stays relaxed. you either go early militaristic, conquer your closest neighbors then mimic good guy for the rest of the game, or full militaristic and conquer all map. I found no in between.

tldr: if you value little to no reward in exchange for your game sunken hours, it's for you. otherwise, just don't

SId Meier's Civilization series is the kind of game series that keep you entertained without even knowing. You may start the game because you heard of its notorious addictive nature, alternate history building, challenging strategy system. However the beauty of it is not in the mechanism. The most interesting bit of the game is that you get to create your own narrative and the possibilities are quite endless. Civilization VI was not perfect but that doesn't mean it was great. In fact, the game was just as entertaining and challenging as we all expected it to be. Do we wish it was more complex and thought-out? Sure, however this game is something that I can always rely on. I am just excited about the next installment.

I would NOT recommend this game. It is quite fun and addictive at first, but once you have mastered the single-player mode, you will be not only metaphorically, but also literally, addicted to it. You will crave the opportunity to test you skill with human co-players online, but you will discover that the online modality is complete and utter unplayable rubbish. You will keep getting extremely frustrating disconnects, broken games, and never-ending loophole exploit nonsense that will keep you in a permanent state of dissatisfaction. But you will keep trying, because you are addicted, and you just can't let go of the desire to recreate your initial single-player experience online. The effects of this game in your daily life can be compared to hard liquor addiction. STAY AWAY!!!

Firaxis' formula for Civ games is well established at this point: you ought wait for all the expansions/updates/DLC to release before buying on a sale. So when Civ 6 came out, I shrugged. Civ 5 remained my go to 4X game, until now. I can confidently say that Civ 6 (as it is now, with all content and updates) is broadly a better game. I really did not expect it to be as much an improvement as it is.
Pros:
-Mechanical depth
There is just so much more to interact with in Civ 6 compared to 5. Most importantly, each system is fleshed out enough that you can focus on exploiting a select number of them in a playthrough, without feeling like there is a "meta" (Science was king in Civ 5. It is still relevant, but not to the same degree)

-Districts and Wonders in the overworld
The district system is the highlight of the game. However, the underlying part of this that is most important is just how much more significant the map is. City placement and planning is critical, not only for said districts but for wonders as well.

-Uniqueness of Civilizations
Civ 5 introduced "unique abilities" for Civs in an attempt to make subsequent playthroughs feel fresh. While there were a few stand outs, there were also a number of boring/bad abilities (America, Netherlands, France, etc). Unique abilities in Civ 6 are now split between both the leader and the civilization itself, and Firaxis was overall MUCH more inventive with them. Additionally, a result of the split is some civilizations having multiple leaders to choose from, allowing for a different strategic focus with the same civilization on a new playthrough! 

-No more national happiness
Civ 6 returns to a system more similar to Civ 4, where you now have a "per city" happiness condition. Some people might prefer the "grow tall" Civ 5 meta. Civ 6 flips that completely, with there being minimal penalty for making new cities. Personally, I prefer it.

-Graphics
I, like many others, had a negative impression of the graphics. When I first saw the cartoony art style around the games release, I thought it was a step backwards. However, I think I was wrong. In placing so much more of the city on the map, additional detail is added. You get to see the buildings you construct in your districts. Wonders show a sped up movie detailing their construction upon completion, and afterwards remain on the map. You get a much better sense of building up your empire than you did in previous games.

-Mods and Scenarios in online multiplayer
A nice addition. It is possible to unofficially patch Civ 5 to enable multiplayer mods, but not scenarios. And of course, all players need said patch. With Civ 6, you avoid this hassle.

Cons:
-AI
I've seen some comments claim the AI is worse than Civ 5. Personally I think that's hyperbolic, as it is probably impossible to be dumber than the Civ 5 AI. Civ 6 is probably about the same; I have yet to witness any great military strategy from the AI. That said, this is not a deal breaker for me. Civ games are more about managing your civilization than about being a challenging strategy game. I do appreciate the enhanced combat that Civ 5 introduced, and wish the AI could be somewhat more capable with it, but it is just one element of the game.

-No source code
If you were hoping to fix the prior issue with mods (like the Civ 5 community patch), you are out of luck. Firaxis has not released the source code, and it seems they never will for this game. No source code = no DLL mods = no modified AI.

-Difficulty modes
Higher difficulty modes still just provide a bunch of bonuses for the AI. What would be most optimal is removing the starting unit/tech/civic bonuses and replacing them with bonus yields over the course of the game (similar to what the Civ 5 community patch does). There are some mods that attempt to do this, but an official implementation would be preferable. As it stands, the "hard" part is just getting past the AI in the early and mid game. Just like in Civ 5, once you are ahead you will trounce them. So the harder difficulties are more of an annoyance than anything.
It would be even more interesting if the AI could scale based off difficulty, but that is probably too much to ask.

-Audio
Don't get me wrong, there is some nice music in the game. My main complaint is in regards to the music that plays while at peace. The game likes to play the themes of other civs you've encountered in the game. This is rather jarring; I much preferred the more "neutral" music that played for the bulk of the game in Civ 5 aside from your leaders theme and the war theme of the civs you'd go to war with. It annoyed me enough to get me to turn down/off the music at times, which I never did in Civ 5.

-2K Launcher
It can be disabled with a launch command, but it is annoying that I have to do that. Steam is a launcher, we do not need more launchers. Game publishers need to stop this.

-2K Account
No, I don't want to link a 2K account, stop asking me. It is thankfully possible to utilize cloud saves for the PC version. You just need to make sure you manually tick the "cloud" option in the save menu when saving. I assume this utilizes steam cloud saves, even though it is not referenced in the steam library like other games. Additionally you can edit the mod ID for the "scout cat" mod to access it without linking an account. Sadly, this does not work for the Caesar DLC, but Trajan seems to be a better leader anyway (free monuments).

I give the game a thumbs up, but only just barely.  On the plus side, it's a beautiful game.  On the down side, it's way more baffling than previous iterations.  It's hard to get visibility into some crucial things in the game - such as tourism and amenities.  There's so much stuff going on that it sometimes feels like you're just blundering your way along rather than guiding anything.  All-up, though, I think that both of those sore points add depth to the game, so I'm not sure they're really all-up bad.

Prior civ games (particularly 5) introduced some ideas that made victory-by-conquest a less-than-easy path to follow.  In 6, it feels dumb to do anything but conquest.  There doesn't seem to be anything that makes bigger empires harder to manage than smaller ones.  The "Warmonger" debuff, which I suppose is intended to make you stop, ends up just keeping you on the path.

They've added a new "religious victory" idea, but it's basically a rehash of conquest victory and happens at a pace that has no kind of historical precedent.  Further, there's no destabilizing effect from having more than one religion in your empire and no destabilizing or negative effect from forced-conversions.  Religion is far and away my least-favorite thing in civ-6.

Still, all-up, it's a civ game, so it starts from a good place.  There's certainly a lot of depth to this game so long-term-playability is certainly there and it's very easy on the eyes.

-- some ammendments after playing for a while --

The more I play it, the more I like it, as some of those opaque things become clearer to me.  Further, mods have fixed many of the things that are broken, and the workshop integration and modding support in the game seem very good.  The biggest charm to me is that there's seemingly endless depth to the game.  The more you discover the more you find there is yet to discover about it.  Even if you're completely clueless, you can still have fun playing it by dialing the difficulty back.  I mean, if you do that, you'll feel like you're being dragged along by events more than controlling the action, but as you learn, you'll feel more in control.

Civ 6 fails miserably where it's predecessor did: AI is just dumb, especially when considering tactical decisions. The other great shortcoming is that the AI cannot compete with human w/o ridiculous advantages - difficulty levels mean something like +40% of everything. And lastly this game has no meaningful catch-up mechanics that I can deduce, if a civilization is bigger, it will have more of everything and the advantage can only grow. The UI isn't nowhere as good as Humankind and Old World, with missing explanations to buttons, completely useless civilopedia and bugs. 
BUGS. Like WTH? Such a high-profile game and I first tried it 8 years after release, and still so many bugs! The worst offender is the Linux native version which leaks like crazy (after a while the game slows down considerably and if you don't restart the game it will grind to a freeze), play the windows version via Proton.

I've played Civ 3, 4, 5, and now 6.  I bought 6 on a sale a while ago and recently decided to finally play it.

Well, I like the new graphic style.

Granted, I've only played 7 hours - but each of those 7 hours I was feeling like I wanted to quit and do something else.

- I don't feel any sense of accomplishment
- I don't feel any anticipation of discovering new land
- I don't feel any anticipation of reaching new levels of tech, religion, or civics
- I don't have any sense of how my civ is progressing or what's happening in my civ.
- not a fan of the new city by city management.
- I find the GUI to be annoying and inconsistent.
- I loathe the World Congress.
- I'm not a fan of the parallel civics and tech trees and the associated bonuses make the progression feel irrelevant.
- In the 7 hours, I experienced a game freeze.

There's going to be others who've learned to enjoy it... but in my opinion this iteration is 3/10.

[h1]Become The Greatest Civilization![/h1]
Civilization VI is the newest installment in the award winning Civilization Franchise. Expand your empire, advance your culture and go head-to-head against historyâ€™s greatest leaders. Will your civilization stand the test of time?

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ’¾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Now the graphics may not be for everyone. The artstyle is more cartoony than the other games (well from what I saw). I actually donâ€™t mind it. The environments look pretty good and the character models (although cartoony) look great, although some leaders do look kinda off. The UI is kinda messy at times and can be pretty overwhelming for new players. The unit models and cities do look incredible (especially when you see your civilization grow). Also the wonders look really beautiful in this game. I really enjoyed the style here. Itâ€™s different and feels unique.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ®Gameplay[/td]
        [td]Now this is my first Civilization game so I canâ€™t compare the other ones so do be warned. This game is really detailed in terms of mechanics. Many factions feel unique from each other (stronger than others at certain eraâ€™s). Early game feels pretty diverse and fun to go through. I especially love how decisions early on make a big impact. Making allies to help you defend against barbarians or enemy factions, or try and create peace with those leaders. The interactions with other leaders are really cool. Diplomacy is kinda inconsistent at times. Some Civ leaders will hate you for performing well, and some others will hate you after you annex an entire country "In Self Defense" when another AI attacks you for no reason. Itâ€™s a hit or miss at times and can get pretty annoying. You even have to manage your culture, government, religion, Technology and civic treeâ€™s, and so on! This game has tons of mechanics and content that will keep bringing you back to improve your skills, experience, and experiment with different Civs. The cool thing about Civs, is that each one has their own abilities that can make each Civ pretty unique from each other. Now the game does have some problems. AI can be pretty silly. Just like how I talked about Diplomacy, they can feel pretty inconsistent at times. The AI also just doesn't feel aggressive even on higher difficulties. The locations they settle as well are just horrible, and the decisions they make are questionable at best. The game has many good mechanics, but there are some annoying issues that I wish would be fixed.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ­Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]Itâ€™s pretty bad. Even without mods, you will get desync like crazy. This is a real shame because Playing with friends can be pretty fun when you get a match together. Being able to ally and take on the world or fight each other or create peace is addicting and has a ton of replayability. You also get many options on how you want to create your lobby. You can pick the game speed, what Civs to play with, the map, and much more. If there is a fix please let me know but for me and my other friends, it was near unplayable.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ•›Playtime[/td]
        [td]You can add hundreds of hours into this game without a doubt! Many Civs feel unique, the maps are amazing and the mechanics are really good (for the most part). You also have a Steam Workshop which will add even more playtime. The amount of replayability is amazing. If you are a strategy/sandbox fan then you might add hundreds of hours on here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ§Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound effects are pretty good. The subtle soundtrack is nice and the voice acting (especially for the loading screen) is superb. Thereâ€™s not really much to add on here. The overall environment and units also sound really good too. I have no complaints here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]â—Bugsâ—[/td]
        [td]I havenâ€™t really come across any bugs. The game does feel pretty polished from my experience. There may be some small ones, but nothing game breaking.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ”…Performance[/td]
        [td]Performance is really good. Playing on Max settings I had a stable 60fps with no stutters or crashes (well besides Multiplayer).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]âœ”ï¸Proâ€™s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Amazing artstyle
[*]Steam Workshop
[*]Solid trade mechanics
[*]Tons of Era's to go through
[*]Easy to learn for new players
[*]Civs feel unique from each other
[*]Culture and religion play a big role
[*]Government mechanics are really good
[*]Good overall soundtrack and voice acting
[*]Can create the way you want to play (game speed, pick an era, how many civs to go against, many maps, etc)
[/list]
[/td]

    [tr]
        [td]âŒConâ€™s[/td]

[*]Wonders take a whole tile
[*]Multiplayer has dsync issues
[*]Diplomacy is inconstant and frustrating
[*]AI are too easy and timid even on higher difficulties
[*]Some Civs are pretty unbalanced (bad for multiplayer)
[*]Base game feels pretty repetitive (get Anthology bundle)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ†Rating[/td]
        [td]7/10 (Singleplayer)
5/10 (Multiplayer)
Get the Anthology Bundle on sale for around 75% off[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]ğŸ”—Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Civilization VI is a great game for anyone into turn-based strategy games. This was my first ever Civilization game and I had a good time with it. You have many Civs to choose from with many cool maps and mechanics such as government, districts, politics, religion, diplomacy, etc. Sadly I donâ€™t recommend the base game since it does lack some needed mechanics to spice up the replayability (such as natural disasters for example). If you are looking to play with friends then skip this game since you will deal with many dsync issues (well from my experience). Wait for a sale and get the Anthology bundle if you want to give this one a try.[/td]
    [/tr]

This game is way different now and it actually fun. I love the district system as it add a emphasis on expanding your empire to get different districts and different bonus. Civ 5 if one city had crazy production then the other cities would not become important and also you were allowed to build almost every single wonder in the game in one city. In Civ 6 you cant do that and that also make an emphasis on expanding and conquering. It allows the AI to have more chances of getting advantages in the game. You also now need to have a constant streamline of builders so you can repair from natural disaster,or build improvement to get either strategic,luxury,and bonus resources. The loyalty system in the game create boundaries for civilization into expanding near your territory and thus being able to get resources that are near your border instead of Civ just building cities literally one title away from your border. I also really like the modes such as the Barbarian clan mode because it make you question on if you want a city state ally later on in the game or   or destroy the barbarian encampment and that make the game much more strategic. It also  allows you to see if you want a buffer state against a certain Civilization. The only draw back with the game is it cartonny art style. The art style make it lose it realism that it had with Civ 5 and i hope that it changes it art style in Civilization 7

Trash game. launcher has been crashing for nine months. Look at my play time. I've got 12 minutes in nine months. This week i found a way to bypass the launcher bc my friends wanted me to play so we researched online. 

I uninstall, verify, try diff computers. Nothing worked. 

then i find a LAUNCH OPTION to bypass launcher - SUCCESS - Or so i was certain...

I get into a multi match and take a few minutes to pick a faction because there is ZERO INDICATION of what you own or NOT. 

I have to click ONE BY ONE through the whole list, make notes, then check faction specs. 

Then i give up - I literally gave up on that bc of time. I then picked RANDOM faction and we begin to load.

While overall the game is great, there are reasons I cannot leave a "positive" opinion when given the binary choice. Civ VI continues the half-assed nature of no-dlc Civ V â€“ Civilization VI is literally unplayable without Gathering Storm. The DLC introduces the grievances system without which the enemies may basically poop on your face without a way for you to retaliate that wouldn't kill your diplomacy for the reminder of the session.

But even after you pay to unlock the normal version, technical issues still await you. Apparently modern systems (SIGNIFICANTLY more powerful than what was available at the release date) with 1Gb/s internet are not enough to handle a 2 human player + 10 AI game on a Large map, because it lead to desyncs every 1-5 turns after a while.

No matter how enjoyable the game is when it works, it would be against my morals to give it a positive review when the players receive such a technical distaster.

As the game has added more content, the fundamental design flaws have begun to completely swamp the game.

This is most obvious with the fact that each city can literally only build one thing at a time. Not even parallel unit & building construction. I know this is classic Civ design, but it does not work for shit anymore. Not when you can't stack units, when it takes 5+ turns for a simple builder. And builders are a key example of how bad the game has gotten.

They get arbitrarily wiped out by random environmental effects - setting you back 5 turns, are still only good for three things when they're expensive & fragile, and those three buildings can also get arbitrarily wiped out by random environmental effects.

There's so much to love about the game, but they need to completely overhaul the basics unless you want to spend all evening re-rolling your starts and save-scumming to get around pure bad luck.

It's an interesting game. Compared to Civilization V, there are a lot of differences, of which many are good and bad. The art style is kind of cool and it prevents the game from falling into the uncanny valley. Overall it's very different from what I'm used to but it's pretty fun to play. Either I'm brain damaged or it feels like some mechanics were made with politics in mind, like how nuclear energy has half as much carbon emissions as oil power plants. Generally doesn't seem correct.

I've been a fan of the series since the first Civilization came out on 5 1/4" floppies, and have watch the series evolve over the decades. This version refines elements of Civ V, and introduces some new concepts, such as the districts city development, that increase the complexity of game options. There are things to love about every game in the series, while I'm sure there will always be features missed from previous versions, or changes that were not liked by some players. For a long time, Civ IV was my main GoTo for the series, after moving on from Civ II, but Civ VI has supplanted Civ IV for me as the most played. I still return to Civ IV at times, but enjoy the many expansions for this version that have improved some of the faults of this version, and have introduced a wide range of options for playstyle. AI has its issues at times, but all-in-all, I thoroughly enjoy this game, and am excited to see what will be kept from this title in the next iteration.

Big Catan

I've long been a Civ player, and for many years I loved 5 the most. I think after the better part of a decade since release, Civ VI is probably THE definitive way to experience the franchise. you can tell an immense amount of work went into the systems of this game to keep it engaging and interesting. Most of the fun of Civ is knowing that you have somewhat of a plan, but executing that plan in the most optimal way is really very difficult, there's so many systems to balance that unless you REALLY know what you are doing you will play sub-optimally, and that's okay. It is incredibly satisfying to see your plans you made a hundred turns ago finally come to fruition. 

I think Firaxis actually want you to be a bit overwhelmed with all the systems, and much like a really life leader of a nation might, you continue to come to grips with these systems and how they interact with each other, stacking bonuses as you get better at the game and more competent at making the correct decisions. I think that's awesome, because it allows the skill expression and skill ceiling of this game to be incredibly high - in my opinion, it is much higher than Civ V. 

My ONE gripe with the game is that there is simply no real option to build tall instead of wide if you want to be competitive. Because of the way district adjacency bonuses work, you pretty much need to make a boatload of cities and bunch them together to get the most out of your districts. Its a shame because in past games, production and economy maxxing by only making like one or two cities was actually really viable and a fun way to play. Hell, they even had Venice as a playable nation in Civ V where you were only ALLOWED to make one city! and you got a ton of bonuses to trade to make it more equitable and interesting. I LOVE the districts in VI, i think they make the game much more engaging, but I wish there was a way to build taller. 

Only other nitpick is diplomatic victory and the world congress still suck and are super boring to play around, and after two expansions and 8 years since launch there is no economic victory condition. All the other victory conditions are great, Religion especially has improved tenfold over previous installments of Civ. 

I really do love this franchise and I think its safe to say after many years, this game has surpassed Civ V for me. Civilization VI is the leader of the pack in 4x grand strategy games, and I suspect it will stay that way until Civ VII finally releases in the year 2050.

"Sid Meierâ€™s Civilization VI" is a strategy game developed by Firaxis Games and published by 2K Games. The game provides players with a deep strategic experience, including managing a civilization, exploration, diplomacy, war management, and cultural development. Here is a general review of the "Sid Meierâ€™s Civilization VI" game:

Graphics and Art Design:
"Civilization VI" has a colorful and detailed graphic style. The game stands out with various art designs representing different civilizations. Cities on the map, natural features, and other elements are aesthetically rich.

Gameplay and Strategy:
The game focuses on historically managing a civilization. Players govern their own civilizations, explore new lands, build cities, conduct diplomacy, and manage wars. Strategic thinking, resource management, and long-term planning are fundamental elements of the game.

City Building and Civilization Development:
The configuration of cities and the development of civilizations offer various strategic options depending on the player's style. Developing civilization by focusing on different elements such as culture, science, trade, and military power is possible.

Diplomacy and Civilizations:
Players can establish diplomacy with other civilizations, make trade agreements, or engage in wars. Agreements and diplomatic relationships significantly influence the overall dynamics of the game.

Multiplayer Mode:
"Civilization VI" includes multiplayer modes, allowing players to compete or collaborate with others globally.

Critiques and Praises:
The game generally receives praise for its strategic depth, diverse civilizations, and the extended duration of gameplay. However, some players might criticize certain mechanics or the behavior of artificial intelligence.

Conclusion:
"Sid Meierâ€™s Civilization VI" offers a rich experience for players interested in strategy games. With its deep strategic elements, historical themes, and extensive in-game options, it stands out as a notable title. It is recommended for players who want to manage and develop historical civilizations.

The game is nice, I like it. The only thing that bugs me is the amount of time it requires. If you want to play casually, one map can take up to a week to finish, which is crazy. Even if you set the game speed to "online" (which is basically double the normal speed), it takes many hours to finish one game.

The game is quite complex, with many variables. At first the number of options can look overwhelming, but it gets easier to navigate as you progress through the game. Despite the number of civilizations the core game-play is the same.

When it comes down to city planning, the UI is just dull and very limited. Yes, there are couple of tricks that can help you, but overall you must have some mods installed for comfortable experience. This is a bit upsetting as I don't really want to dive into this whole modding thing.

I haven't played any other Civ's, but I really like this one. The only criticism I have isn't about the gameplay--just that the "barbarians" mechanic is pretty messed up.
Barbarians are separate from any civilizations, but they're not considered civilizations or city-states themselves. Your only options for interacting with them are kill them or, with DLC, bribe them. They don't have borders or anything--they're arbitrarily deemed to have no right to the land they reside on. Yet they're everywhere on the map.

I think Civilization V is a whole lot better. I don't know what other retardation I might find but I'll play it a little more just in case. Between civ 4 - 6 I probably have about 4k hours. Its my fav game of all time. Anyone who is a fan of historical narratives and the 4x genre will probably enjoy this game. It requires a sizable time commitment, not only in learning the game, but to finish a game as well. 6-8 hour games are not uncommon but well worth the satisfaction. Forgive me for making a sports analogy in a gaming community, but its a lot like baseball. Many can't stand the "slow" pace and length. Many also can't stand the flurry of categories and numbers associated with baseball statistics. For those of us who truly enjoy baseball, like civ, its a rewarding experience. We look forward to squeezing out every turn, meticulously planning our government, and making strategic decisions on the battlefield.
The graphics are nice in this game compared to prior games.  I did not like not being able to move spies around, but the idea is nice.

They made this game as annoying as they possibly could have. Unless you enjoy 800 pointless popups every single turn, just play Civ 5. It's still much better. The improvements this game brings are not worth the massive nuisance the AI has become. It's just so frustrating they decided to make the annoying aspects of previous games the main focus of this one, and gave you no way to customize the game to get rid of the constant annoyances they added into this game. If you're hoping for the AI to not be as obnoxious as possible, you're looking at the wrong civ game. Diplomacy with the AI is completely pointless, they'll denounce you 2 turns after meeting you, declare war when you have friendly relations, denounce you for things that aren't actually true about your civ, and INUNDATE you with pointless pop-up messages from them that add nothing to the game. The AI also will spam cities into ANY unheld territory you have, no matter what. They literally took the AI and made it as annoying as it could possibly be, while still being a complete fucking imbecile when it comes to diplomacy and fighting wars. Find another game that put more than 10 seconds into creating their AI

Having been an avid fan of the Civilization franchise since the first game came out in the early 90's, I must say I get more and more disappointed with every release. Sure, the games look better for each new version, but the playability gets worse and worse, and the 6th incarnation is in my humble opinion a steaming pile of you-know-what. What used to be a nice beer-and-pretzels game, has turned into a game of endless micro-management and confusing mechanics, and that takes the joy out of playing it. If I could, I would return it, and I would not recommend anyone to buy it.

When choosing Dominant Victory, most gamer will probably be annoyed by the bunch of encampments built by the AI. Especially when a large number of cities need to be taken down, it will take a lot of time to just take down the encampment districts. Hereby, Recommendations for this area of â€‹â€‹the military camp are summarized below:

    I hope the encampment district can have a more intuitive positioning and upgrade route: Such as a castle (fortress) dedicated to defense; a military camp (Military Academy) dedicated to producing troops and providing great general points.

---------------------On the castle(fortress) route, you can be given long-range attack capabilities and city wall defenses, but there is no bonus to troop production, and it does not grant productivity or great general points. As the game reaches later stages, castles built during certain eras can provide cultural bonuses.

---------------------On the military camp (Military Academy) route, you can not get the long-range attack capabilities, and it only has the health of the area itself and no wall defenses. However, it has various productivity bonuses when producing units, as well as the productivity bonus of the area itself. .The great general points are awarded through the combat merits of the production units in this city.

The core gameplay is great, but the AI is so garbage that Iâ€™ve discovered I never had a satisfying match. Itâ€™s like playing a game of soccer against toddlers. 
Hereâ€™s a list of things the AI is bad at, or will never do:
â€¢	They donâ€™t use generals strategically.
â€¢	When they get an admiral, they sail it around like a scout and never use its bonus.
â€¢	If you do not share a border with a Civ you are at war with, they will never be a threat because the AI cannot comprehend moving units in a way that is not linear.
â€¢	I have never seen an AI put aircraft on an aircraft carrier.
â€¢	I have never seen an AI use a weather balloon with artillery. Without the weather balloon, artillery is essentially useless.
â€¢	I have never seen an AI use a medic. (Guruâ€™s yes, however).
â€¢	I have never seen an AI build a fort. (not an encampment).
â€¢	Naval combat is pathetic. One time a few of my frigates ran into an enemy submarine. The sub could have destroyed my ships, but it never attacked, and I was able to whittle the sub down in a few turns and kill it. This made no sense.
Every game play s out the same. All AI are very powerful and aggressive at the beginning, but if you are able to survive to the Industrial Era, all AI, no matter the difficulty, just starts to disintegrate. AI doesnâ€™t seem to know how to build a modern military. If you destroy its military in the medieval era, they donâ€™t seem to build it back. Letâ€™s be honest, combat is the most fun part of the game, so the fact that the AI is so terrible at it takes away the best part of the game. 

When you donâ€™t align with their ideals, they have to interrupt the game to tell you constantly. Itâ€™s super annoying and childish.
good

Sid Meierâ€™s CivilizationÂ® VI is a triumph in the strategy genre, offering a deeply engaging experience from the ancient era to the information age. With its diverse civilizations, each with unique traits, and a robust district system, the game excels in delivering strategic depth and replayability. The AI opponents are challenging, making diplomacy and war exciting and unpredictable. The evolving soundtrack is a delightful touch, enhancing the immersion.

However, be prepared for a slower pace in the late game, as turns can become lengthy and the gameplay slightly less dynamic. Despite this, Civilization VI remains a standout title, offering hours of compelling gameplay for strategy enthusiasts. Highly recommended for its depth and complexity, with a small note on the late-game pacing.

As someone who credits CIV5 for being so good it ended my MMO addiction, I feel like an addict never able to get the hit I want when I play CIV 6.

As a Canadian, it's great finally being able to play as my country, and when I saw this month's special event, I decided to load it up again, but first play through the game on prince to refresh myself. Of course, it didn't take very long to remind me what I dislike so much about this version of the game.

Start Game feels too much like the hunger games. Between all the barbarians coming in from all sides, combined with the other city-states and civs getting a little too close for the liking, I always feel so much pressure to be very aggressive with a strong military at the beginning - except the game I would prefer to play is peaceful and explorative . . . and that seems to involve a whole lot of "options tuning" on my parent to make it happens, which I don't like having to do. I think the game has a "standard" format, and I don't like doing things such as removing barbardians when I think they are supposed to be an intended part of the experience.

Related to the above point, with so many civs battling for resources, there's a huge need to have many many settlers and city creation. So the early game involves to much flag posting while you maintain various mediocre cities. I really enjoyed being able to turtle in CIV 5, as well as just focusing on at most 10 cities by end game. In CIV 6, I feel I need 10 cities just be turn 100!

First off, I've been playing Civ since 1995 with the release of Civilization 2. This version VI is the most unstable version I have ever played. I'm done with Civilization VI, what a big dissappointment!

There are a number of issues with this game, if you come from console you'd know them well, and the modding is pretty terrible, however, if you do enjoy a long strategy type game and don't mind spending a lot of time I'd still recommend it, just be careful with mods and test it when you can. Also, if you're having any problems (might work on console to an extent,) keep your save amount low. by that I mean the more games you have saved the more problems are likely to occur, so keeping that low and painfully finishing your games should help.  Another thing, I'd wait till its on sale as the dlc prices are outrageous but are basically needed if you want to have a better experience.

I have been playing for a long time now, and I have had my issues, but recently a game breaking issue has stopped me from being able to even load my saves after it decided to start a random game earlier. There is barely any support for bug fixes either, so I can't recommend this after its abandonment and issues.

five stars from me.

Serviceable if you already like Civ games, but solves none of the franchise's decades-old problems.

You'll have fun building your base, until you realise you are facing inactive, irrational AI players with poorly scaled difficulty settings, followed by a slog of a late game where you get to make few significant choices. Most games deteriorate into waiting a long time to watch a long-predetermined outcome play out.

The only really playable mode, multiplayer, has loads of technical problems, though it's not quite a buggy mess. When you get the settings, map, and win condition dynamics right it can be really fun - but that's all on the players, not the game, and you have to play a lot of bad games before you know how to do it.

This game is OK. It was barely worth the $6 (90% off) price and it feels like a kinda rushed small-team indie game. If this game currently costs more than $10, consider this to be a negative review.

The reviews for the DLC are almost entirely negative, so I only bought the base game.

The art style is tacky. It tries to look charming, but feels empty and shallow like corporate clip-art. The interface sucks in many different ways that aren't game-breaking individually, but add up to provide a constant baseline level of annoyance for the player.

For this studio, it should be considered a huge embarrassment that it's so clunky, poorly designed, and ugly. For the sixth iteration of the game, though, there should be honorable auto-minecrafting from the people responsible.

I have been playing all the Civ games since the first one in the mid-1990's. I recently even tried playing the early Civ's. But they have not aged well. I would hate to think how many thousands of hours I spent (not lost?) playing these games. But I must say that CIV 6 is indeed the best one yet. There now two trees, one for tech and another for social changes more sophisticated than CIV 5. AI is better, especially for the city-states, but even for the other civ's (a peeve of mine from the beginning). I actually do like the new idea of developing regions around the cities and not just putting everything into the cities, completely new from the past civ's. The game is much faster to complete, which I think is good, too. One can combine military units into corps to enable up to three in a hex. 

But I do have two complaints, one huge and one trite. The trite one is that instead of using historical faces, all civ leaders look like something out of a Disney movie. They are all goofy looking and some of the kings appear like they spend 4 hours body building a day. But my main complaint which is related to how fast the games end is that the tech tree ends about 30 years in the past. There are no future technologies except for the generically described "future tech". Previous civ's, especially the earlier ones, went boldly into the future by generations. This is very strange for me. Nonetheless, endlessly replayable with some real improvements (except for the short tech tree) I give this a 9/10.

Everything is super cartoonish and dumb, barbarians are more powerful than any early civilization because they can spam troops back to back making them completely OP. It's a mix of; 
-Settlers of catan (with hex shape tiles that are new every game)
-7 Wonders (you literally build every wonder you can think of throughout the game)
-and most importantly RISK (you can fight and conquer or play it chill and build up)

I have 1 or 2 hours on the game so far.. i have currently got a win with 60 or so civs out of 80 ish civs... The replay ability is great.

There are things i hope they add in the next game or a DLC.. some reason you cant unbuild districts and other buildings... meaning a miss click can ruin the layout of your city... Unit pathing you need to pay attention to as if there is a unit on the choke point tile, your unit will bugger off the wrong way trying to go around the mountains or whatever rather than patiently wait a turn for gap to open up... can be a real pain in the ass. I have other gripes, but they are all small. The game is great fun and i highly recommend it.
