I absolutely love this game! I have played for thousands of hours on all platforms in total. A must-have for every gamer.

Too much of what they ultimately set out to achieve in this game falls flat on its face in its execution

unique great people: The idea of Einstein giving you a different buff to that of Plato is interesting but in reality, you are in a position to just meta-pick certain scientists with some having major benefits in comparison to others. 

Districts: overall a stupid idea. Why would I have to build a library for my city in a district that is several tiles away a mountain range? Takes away the city-building aspect you had from CIV5. realistically, these districts should be optional should you wish to optimise a particular city for a function ie: religion, science etc. 

Art: The other reviewers are idiots, it looks like a mobile game.  The fog of war is very irreparable at times as well, CIV5's fog of war is much greater on the eye as here you are stuck in a black and white view of lands you do not have coverage of. The Cities themselves feel very limited and do not grow past a certain size on the map. In CIV5 your cities would visibly grow into metropolises as the population grew but here it looks to be stagnant once you pass level 10+ in pop.

Wonders: Make sense that some wonders take up a tile ie: pyramids, but as you get through the game, your lands end up looking like a monopoly board with all these random buildings scattered everywhere. There is also an over-exaggeration of geographical and district requirements to build wonders. 

units: to keep having to build workers after their use  and having to rely on trade to build roads, excluding Rome, makes the early game feel monotonous.

Misc: 
The game tells you information in a much more ugly way in comparison to CIV5:
- when a wonder is built it will never show you which one was built like in CIV5, you now have to hover over the icon in the bottom right.

The golden ages function is cringe, you are punished for not playing in a certain way the game wants you to play. 

Movement is clunky and changed unnecessarily compared to CIV5. makes early game scouting and war play like a ball ache.

I've had a shit ton of hours in the Epic Games version of Civilization VI (since they offered the base game for free) before I got the game on Steam with all the DLC this December.

It's a really solid game! The gameplay is engaging, the visuals are pretty great, and there's a lot of variety in how you can play the game. The DLCs are brilliant too, especially Rise & Fall and Gathering Storm. There's even a battle royale mode, if you want that from a strategy game for some reason.

I'd definitely recommend it if you have an interest in strategy games or history.

However, I will tell you the game is still overpriced for all it's worth. This is the kind of game you get on sale, not for the full cost. But when it goes on sale, it's usually for an absolute steal of a price (I got the game and all of the DLC for like, half the cost of the base game, for reference).

Also, if you're a Linux user like me, make sure to use Proton instead of running the game natively. The native version doesn't have monthly challenges for some reason.

The game introduces innovative features such as unstacked cities and districts, enhancing strategic depth. The diverse array of leaders and civilizations provides replayability, each offering a unique playstyle. However, the game's complexity might be overwhelming for newcomers. With its captivating historical context, engaging diplomacy, and the thrill of guiding a civilization from ancient times to the space age, "Civilization VI" stands as a formidable and rewarding strategy title for fans of the genre.

Civilization is a fantastic 4X game which is deep enough to entertain you for hundreds of hours but accessible enough that anyone can play it without knowing a lot about math or history. 

After those hundreds of hours you might start complaining about certain mechanics that you don't like, but you would never argue that the game isn't worth the money you spent on it. 

If you haven't played Civ 5 it's probably worth starting there because you can get it very cheap on sale. If you are still in love with Civ 5 and are wondering if Civ 6 is a big jump forward, I'd say it's not, really. But as someone with 800 hours in Civ 5 and has finally reached a point where it's not fun anymore, Civ 6 offers enough differences to make it feel fresh again. 

Particularly I like that each tech has it's own 'quest' that if completed gives a huge boost towards learning it. E.g. finding a natural wonder gives a big boost to learning Astrology. This helps each playthrough feel more unique as you may be tempted to take different routes depending on what quests are easily completed for you. Also Civ 6 does not punish you for expansion like Civ 5 does, which suits my playstyle better.

So far I only played 15h so far compared to my 2400h in civ 5 and while I'm hoping it will grow on me sooner than later, so far it's pretty confusing, overstimulating and at times straight up frustrating. All of which I didn't experience when I first started playing civ 10 years ago...

I think there are a lot of good ideas that build on the previous game, the fundamental problem tho is that the cluttered UI with a lack of meaningful customisation, and the terribly paced, yet bare-bones tutorial make it very frustrating to learn the ropes.

I'm a staunch believer that every game can and should hook you and be fun from the first second, but this one does not make a great first impression. Everyone online seem to recommend sticking it out until it begins to click, and maybe I'll find the patience to do so. People also say to download mods and watch youtube tutorials to imprive the experience and learn the game, which must be a joke, coz that's just a sign of truly obtuse game design.

I can't personally recommend this kind of approach to anyone, when so many other new and old games, civ 5 even, are so much more fun and accessible. 

Tl;dr great fresh ideas undermined by bad onboarding and user interface. More confusing than fun in the first 15h even for an experienced civ player.

Fantastic strategy game.

Players can afford not completely min-maxing their gains, but will be GREATLY rewarded if they do (meaning itâ€™s not 100% necessary to be meticulous if thatâ€™s not you).

You can choose (and switch depending on how your game is going) which sort of victory youâ€™d like to aim for (E.g. Science, Culture, Domination, e.t.c.) and suit your style toward it. There are countless leaders to choose from and fight/befriend (more if you buy expansion packs) and the gameplay is sure to be a hit if you love strategy.

NOT ONLY is the strategy fantastic, but the MUSIC AND ART is like no other. This soundtrack is fabulous should you give it the time, and changes depending on the era youâ€™re currently in within a game (each leader/civilization has their own 4 themes for the respective Ancient, Medieval, Industrial and Atomic game-eras) and it is easy to tell the composers did extensive research into cultural and historical motifs with their writing. 

The voice acting and language is beautiful and really gives a great feel for being a diplomatic giant in-game. Itâ€™s something special.

All settings can be changed to your liking, but keep in mind Civ games are not generally quick or fast-paced in their extreme forms. Civ6 is a strategy game, so if youâ€™re not into that, or wanting to get into that, it might be better to start somewhere a bit lighter. 

(Or just go right in).

There are many things to like about Civ 6, but this is about a final recommendation. I don't think Civ 6 is a game I'd tell people to buy given that there are better choices. If somebody said "Should I spend $60 on Civ 6?" I'd say "No. You should spend a fraction of that and get Civ 4 or 5 (or both) and let that be your first Civ experience.

I've enjoyed every Civ game 1-5, and though they were not always perfect, each had its own appeal for me. So far, Civ 6 has been my first disappointment with the franchise.  Yes, I even liked the notorious 3rd game.

Until Civ 6. 

In this edition, complexity is stacked on complexity simply for its own sake, in the "worst-of" mix of Eurogame mechanics without theme. It's as fun as using Excel to model your real life country's economic strategy. It's "wide over tall" requirement is only suitable for players who think a Civ game should be 20-40 hours of min-max grinding and extreme micromanagement.

While it's prettier than any previous Civ in terms of overall art quality, I absolutely detest the goofy, cartoon-like leaders and overall aesthetic. One thing I must have from Civ in order to even allow it to be grouped in the legacy is taking the world and its history seriously. Starting with the steroid-inflated arms of swole bro Gilgamesh wearing World of Warcraft bracers shown off right on the store page (as if it's something to be proud of), every choice about style is wrong.

On that note, leaders have bafflingly specific and wordy bonuses that read like terms of service, and often don't seem to have anything to do with one another. More, there's often no thematic consistency between the leaders' personalities (as characters from historical narrative) and their bonuses. Civ 1-5's straightforward leader bonuses were simple in concept but powerful in application. 

Years of patches haven't improved the game at all.

However, after playing Civ V, the Civ personalities seem not quite as good, the visuals, policies, governments, and map customization are not my favorite. I would really just recommend playing Civ V. If you want to do have more late game fun in Civ V, SMans World At War mod and associated modpacks are great. In short, Civ VI is not bad, there are some likable things. However, I would just recommend you play V instead of this one. It's just better.


EDIT: I have revisited and played the Rise and Fall ruleset as Julius Caesar. First, Julius Caesar makes it automatically better. I played a game through to the science victory, and I enjoyed it more than the base game rules. There are still a few things I still agree with myself about, like the workers only getting 3 charge, and some new things I wasn't a huge fan of, like just about how the pacing feels off just like in the Civ V game, where the modern era onward feels too fast. Some technologies and civics feel out of order or should come after other techs and civics. All in all, I will be continuing to play it

I invite you to look at this game through several differently-tinted lenses I'll provide you now:

I am very fond of paradox grand strategy games, EUIV probably being my favorite. If I was to describe it in one sentence, I would call it a 'nation roleplaying sandbox game'. Notice how the word strategy was excluded. This does not mean I do not consider that game being part of such genre - the amount of depth and value it can provide is profound. The games biggest strength is the historical flavor that gives you substantial insight into different cultures, religions and events of the era and region that is actually integrated very well into the gameplay itself. Civ 6 can offer plentiful material for keen readers - Civilopedia, which you can open quite quickly and familiarize yourself with trivia on a military unit, world wonder, technological breakthrough or even a policy. What EU IV (and to be fair, no other paradox game) cannot offer, however, is engaging tall/peaceful play. These games are called map painting simulators for a reason - despite thorough work put into making 'passive' gameplay fun, the game ultimately resolves, one way or another, on war. In Civ 6 on the other hand, you can choose not to declare a single war in entire playthrough and have a blast. Questionable for some, but an obvious upgrade from Civ 5 is what they did to cities - it actually requires solid planning, positioning and prioritizing. The district system and wonders occupying a tile to build is merely a surface level aspect of otherwise immensely deep and satisfying part of gameplay - city building.

I am very fond of castle/base building games such as Stronghold Crusader or Age of Empires. As I mentioned, the city building part of civ 6 is truly impressive, requiring you to take into account multiple variables, including visual appeal, dangers of natural disasters (river flooding, sandstorms and droughts) and accessibility of different categories of resources - bonus, strategic, luxury. Of course, the combat of a turn based strategy is incomparable to RTS, yet I want to compliment it under this 'lense' - there is just so much options and layers to seemingly straightforward part of the game that make the aggressive part of 'civilizing process' engaging as well - aircraft, support/siege units, coastal raids, need for previously mentioned strategic resources (good luck fighting modern era wars without oil). That includes also depth regarding war exhaustion, loyalty and potential rebellion. Warmongering might not be as flashy and fun as blowing up castles with horse artillery in AOE3, yet it can offer similar levels of depth regarding combat.

I am very fond of turn based strategy games, Heroes of Might and Magic III being an obvious favorite. I grew up playing this game on hot-seat (multiple people taking turns on one computer) with siblings and friends and now I still play the game online with close ones. The strengths of HoMM are infinite. What I will mention is that civ 6 is nearly just as fun to play with friends in multiplayer. And the (random) map generator that offers so much variety (extended beyond infinity with mods) and different playthroughs that always offer something fresh and engaging.

I am very fond of moddability of the games - both from the point of view as user and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2973448849]mod maker[/url] myself. Not only civ 6 is extensively modded, it is extensively moddable. Unlike some games, the changes you can implement can be so fundamental that it can completely change the way you play civ 6 - new victory conditions, complete overhaul of city building and opening of new tactics. That does not mean that the base game is unplayable, of course It's just that modding may eventually become a natural extension of your civ 6 experience, prolonging your enjoyment of it. Truly, nearly everything you can tune and adjust to your liking.

Now let us change green lenses with red tinted ones.

I am very fond of atmosphere and overall [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EvH2CPEeIHU]mood[/url] of Civilization 5. I fully understand and agree with players who criticize the aesthetic turn Civ 6 made. While some changes were welcome, the game lost stylishness and vibe of the earlier title. In Civ5, the menus, visuals, music and even color palette set the darker, less saturated but more serious mood. When you met different leaders, not only you interacted with their avatar, but also it felt as if you had an actual audience with them in their throne room in their capital - just compare the meeting of Montezuma with meeting with Pedro of Brazil. Even the soundtrack has severe downgrades - I do not imply that the music itself has worsened, but the diversity of implementation. The cool thing is that civs have music based the era they are in, starting with calm and slow ancient era and transitioning to booming and bustling atomic era tracks (check out Hungary theme). However, the game lost division into peaceful/war music. Yeah, if you are under war or in peace times, the music will not change, unlike civ 5 where it created strong dramatic effect. So did the civ 6 lose the '[url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YbNsNnLczg4]regional music[/url]', such as additional non-civ tracks that set the mood and helped you immerse with civilization you are playing as. There are plenty of minor things to nitpick, last one I'll mention are the wonders - when you build one in Civ 6, you get the construction animation of the wonder on a tile where it is in the world. In Civ 5, you can a static, but incredibly cool artwork with chilling sound effect and breathtaking [url=https://youtu.be/PubrHoHpWbM?si=s_eivmGYyWqZelUn&t=576]soundtrack[/url] as a follow up with some badass quote. There were instances where I shed a tear in Civ 5, either from [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DgPDqcsLI58]BNW main theme[/url] and intro, wonder scenes or simply due to emotionally moving [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ULgtHjLmb9Y]music[/url]. In civ 6, I did not even once.

I am, as EVERY player, fond of difficulty and *strategy* in a strategy game. And in turn based one, the difficulty is less so measured in reflexes and reaction as it is in planning and outsmarting. Naturally, you would expect that the harder you set the difficulty of the game, the harder it should be to outsmart the enemy. And here is the fundamental problem of the game that may be enough for you to say 'no': you cannot make AI smarter (even mods cant help much), only give them cheats. You cannot make AI play better, you can give them extra units, resources and percentages (+20% science, culture etc) at the start of the game. In other words, you give them cheats, not brains. While in singleplayer games this can be a profound issue, in multiplayer they function quite well in the role of passenger - instead of offering viable competition, they serve as dynamic entities for real players to interact with - trade, fight, make alliances. This way the AI no longer becomes a major issue for me as I 99% of the time play with friends or siblings.

These are the lenses I see civ 6 with. You may find different shiny spots to praise or smelly stains to spit on, but for me, this is among the greatest strategy games I've ever had the pleasure to enjoy. With so much still left to talk about - unique great people, unique city states, outstanding government mechanics, fleshed out victory types, etc - I'll just conclude the review with statement: Yes, and I like it better than Civ 5 (except vibe, of course).

This game should be way better at this point. 

I've played this game 1300+ hours (yes, very pathetic) and I have a love/hate relationship with it. I've played Civ versions for over 20 years now and really think for the 6th version there are several things that should be better. 

The most annoying thing about this version of the game is are the natural disasters and rising waters. They really messed this up as it's so silly and predictable. I just turn off all disasters and it's fine but the rising waters is so pathetic. Hey its the 1500's, and the water is rising. By the 1600's the water has risen 3meters and there's nothing you can do! You can literally lose 1/3 of your land territory if you're on an island based map. The Dutch first reclaimed land in the 1200's but this game thinks we need Computer technology to mitigate rising waters? And it doesn't matter how much Science you focus on, the years it happens will just come earlier. Plus with some smaller cities that are younger and not such a big population, I've had it take over 100 turns for my flood barrier but I can 1 click create a tunnel in a mountain or create a ski resort. Stupid! 

The game play itself can get very repetitive so when the 'Future Tech/Civ' boxes pop up late game for EVERY TURN, you're ready to smash your screen. That plus the setting up of Trade routes if you get attacked or start a war. There have been games where I had over 200 trade routes and if you get into a war (everyone attacks you) You have to set up those trade routes again ONE BY ONE! That plus the Governor upgrades that come in every turn even though they're all maxed out. You have to go to the governor screen every single turn. 

There's also no 'repeat' button to click for your production. So if you have 20 cities and it's late game, I typically just 'Carbon Recapture' for most of my cities. So you can load 8 items in the 'queue' x 20 cities. So you're clicking literally 160 times every 8 turns. I've had games with 50+ cities, that's hundreds of unnecessary clicks. They could EASILY have a 'Repeat' button to click and boom, that's sorted. 

There are other parts of the game that are super annoying so thank goodness for the workshop with some fixes. There's a housing and amenity one that is great to get rid of the loyalty issues. Theres an awesome one that gives you what's called a 'Reserve' and you can accumulate all strategic resources from Horses, Iron up to Uranium. This allows you to have 1 resource per turn per city so you can get enough to play but not a crazy amount. This actually makes the game much more fun to play. 

Another gripe is that the interface is all over the screen. When you're dealing with 10/20/30+ cities and just grinding through, you are literally clicking all over your screen from corner to corner. I really don't know why they can't have the clickable area all in the same place? Like when some other civ makes a trade request you have to literally click on 3 parts of the screen. You click the 'goodbye' button on the bottom left hand side but then you have to go up to the top right corner to X out of the screen? When you're playing with 7 other civs this can get so draining. 

It's hard to explain but I feel like the difficulty scaling is very tough. I can be at Prince (standard setting) and then go up to the next one and everything is so much more intense it's just not fun. Like at Prince you can manage things fine and it's almost kinda easy and boring so you go up to the next level then all of your opponents gang up on you it can be frustrating in a way. 

So yeah, I'm writing this just as I will uninstall the game. 1300+ hours is stupid. But I've played every civ a few times and won on Diety 2x (but I had to restart and save and go back) so I'm satisfied with getting enough wins. 

I'm not sure what they have in store for 7 but they really need to get the basics (stuff I mentioned above) better otherwise it's just a waste of time and money. They might come up with more gimmicks like say Klaus Schwab and the WTO or incorporate a pandemic feature lol. But I honestly really love the game, I'm sitting here typing this review out reconsidering uninstalling haha. 

The core of the game is great but they've added things (the amount of civs to play as/against is great) that don't make for a more enjoyable experience. I have this with the new Gran Turismo 7. GT4 was much better but we all still want the newest version. So Civ 6 is not the best version of this game. I think maybe it was 4 or 5? But if you are into this turn based style of game Civ is still on top. 

Happy Gaming.

I started Civilization 6 thinking I'd be a military genius, but turns out I'm just a construction worker with delusions of grandeur. And forget war, I'm too busy sending my scouts on an epic quest to find the lost city of El Dorado, while my civilization is crumbling back home. My citizens are probably wondering why we have 20 wonders but no defenses. Sorry, guys, I was too busy chasing Great People like they owe me money.

Fun 4X game. I will admit that I was at first hesitant because I was so religiously devoted to Civ V, but over time this game warmed up to me. The game runs smoothly and many of the new systems are enjoyable, and I personally now prefer it to Civ V. 

Some noteworthy changes I liked:

-The addition of "quests" in the form of Eurekas and Inspirations was clever and makes the game a bit more active and less of an end-turn button masher while also rewarding you for being proactive.

-The city district system is very unique and makes city construction much more interesting. It also feels like city placement and management matters more in this game than in Civ V.

-I enjoy that social policies are researched now similar to sciences. The government system that goes hand-in-hand with this also allows for a lot of freedom and customization.

-The diplomatic victory is admittedly a bit overpowered and too easy to get, however the diplomatic system as a whole matters much more and is more fun. Voting in the World Congress feels more meaningful, and this combined with the more nuanced alliance system makes diplomacy more interesting. Oftentimes in Civ V it felt like diplomacy would always become a bribery contest.

-Religion is not just a meme. It is actually a very legitimate way to play the game, and even if you do not attempt a religious victory Faith is still much more powerful than it was in Civ V.

-Happiness still matters (now in the form of "Amenities") but it is not as insanely punishing to have low Amenities (Happiness) as it was in Civ V. 

-Gandhi still nukes people. Some things never change!

Embarking on my first foray into the world of Civilization, I found myself both intrigued and slightly intimidated by the prospect of navigating the intricate landscapes of history. The varied victory conditions provide multiple paths to success, keeping each play through fresh and engaging.

The map, with its diverse landscapes and dynamic changes over the eras, adds a visually immersive element to the game. The audio contributes significantly to the overall atmosphere.

Whether you're a veteran player or a newcomer to the franchise, Civilization VI offers an unparalleled journey through history that is both challenging and immensely rewarding.

If you think the game is too challenging or complicated do not hesitate to go look for videos explaining the game online. It is essential in order to understand what the game may lack to inform.

There are many moving parts to this game, you can't just pound building and district production until your #1 at everything...I mean, you can, but you just don't get away with that in the upper difficulties. You best be using your brain noodle to plan your cities.
There are more than just barbarians that lurk in the lush forests of the world. Tribal villages bestow advantageous gifts upon you if you decide to explore the map early - scouts scouts!!
Natural wonders wait to be discovered and settled to add boosts to your empire. Wonders wait to be built to gain an edge over your competitors, there are many with land requirements that cannot be seen through the fog of war. City states provide awesome bonuses to their suzerains, especially after their 6th envoy - find those sweet little treasure nuggets and hold them close, lest your enemies swipe them from under your nose....or burn them to the ground.
There are many ways to win the game, and many more to lose it. Plenty of good guides on YouTube on how to achieve each victory type.
If this goes on sale - consider the buy.

It is the unique game which captures the best way the essence of the civilisations evolution. It is not difficult to play it, but it is recommended to give a look to some simple and fast tutorial if you never played games as complex as this one (Hoi4 is more complex by the way).

One of my favourite aspects is the fact we can select real world places map, such as Europe, the world, ecc. and you can also choose if all civilisations will start from their historical geographical origin (example: If you play as the Romans, you will start in Italy if you wish).
It is recommended to play it with friends if you often opt for multiplayer mod in others games.

Expansions+purchase suggestions:
That said, there are many expansions packets which are worth to try (the ambient disasters and diplomatic ones are my favourites) but I recommend to buy them WITH the game as well, when they are in special offer (example: I bought the game + ALL expansions mod packets for just â‚¬24,85 instead of â‚¬209 around the period of 1-4 January), so if you are interested to buy the game with all expansions packets mod I suggest you to control very often when there are these kind of special offers.
If you are interested of buying just the game, you can wait for a special offer period (my brother bought it for just â‚¬5 instead of â‚¬60 around 1-4 January)
NOTE: Remember the periods with special offers/discounts could be present in different periods respectively of the previous ones I mentioned (as much as I know) and/or have different prices respectively the prices I mentioned previously.

Conclusion: 
If you (kind of) like history and complex strategy games, or just having fun to develop a civilisation along time with friends, Civilization VI is definitely a game to try in my opinion.

I started with CIV 1 and played all up to 4. Now tried out 6. For me the fun is gone. Looks like rocket science. When I look back in the long time between CIV 2 and 3 where I had to play alternatives like "Call to Power" it was (for me) a great relief that 3 wasn't that complex. It was easy to lean and play, even after months of not playing. It seems that 6 is targeting the heavy gamer community looking for complex, in-depth and very challenging games.

It's hard to say whats so enchanting about this series. Perhaps it is the history nerd in me. Perhaps it is the stories this game allows you to imagine in your head: What life is like in a particular city or what this current era must feel like for one of your citizens. Perhaps it is the detailed game play loop that always leaves me patiently waiting for the next building to finish or the next war to be over.

Civ 6, I believe, is the highest standard of game play you can find in the series. The districts add so much complexity to planning out your civilization. There is nothing more satisfying than finally placing that tri-city entertainment complex-theater square mega complex. Mastering the game (winning deity difficulty) was one of the most satisfying moments I've had in gaming in recent memory. I hope this series continues to improve and grow.

I have been a long-time fan of this game franchise, but this latest 6th edition, especially the Leader Pass is a huge disappointment. For an AAA game developer company with a 100+ EUR game the launching of their product should go smoothly without any issues. Even if the latest update states that it does not run on Linux, then the developers should ensure that the rest of the game functions properly. On top of that, the developer company sold me an update that not only does not run on my platform, but also makes the whole base game unplayable. Now, after the full update to the Anthology, where the Leader Pass stated will run on Linux by the way, the game not just does not start, but it even refuses to launch on compatibility modes of Proton. Ofc, I do not want a refund, as this game was working fine without the last update. As the last update stated it will run om Linux, otherwise I even would not see the item in my filtered purchase list, I would expect the developers to fix the issue and the game should run on linux smoothly before the company starts to work on any other product, they should not to even think about a Civilization 7 before it is fixed.

So, if you are a turn-based strategy game lover, you are better off by choosing any other game than this one, where the issue is still not fixed after one year have passed since the last update release, and the content packs were issued just as a money grab without putting in some real effort.

Game is mid at best, they've shifted from the realistic SFM art into the cartoony blender art thats trendy now, the new District system is fantastic however it suffers from the game maps not being sized or rendered to accomidate the space taken up by districts, map generation is really broken too, each civ has a start bias based on their civ's boons and malluses like deserts for Mali or steppes for Scythia however it doesnt work, youll constantly find yourself starting on the Worst terrain for your civ for example flat plains as koreans or incas (who want mountains and hills) or in desert/jungle areas as most other civs who want regular grassland. The barbarian system is also Ridiculous in older Civ games if you lost to barbarian hordes it was a complete skill issue however in Civ 6 they are extremely OP it is completely normal to see a barbarian camp produce 5 horsemen and 3 horse archers in the first 20 turns and then pop out of the fog of war and siege your capital, you cant reliably counter this since you dont get walls, archers, or spears, until late dark age and you end up getting locked in gay baby jail forever while the AI surpasses you in tech and you just get gimped. the Tech system with the new research districts when combined with map generation issues also just completely takes the skill out of your hands when building for a science game since its completly RNG based whether or not you get a decent science location and if you do 9 times out of 10 the before mentioned barbarian hordes will just raze the district and sit on it while they besiege you completely locking you out of science and the whole game for the first hundred turns while you slowly widdle them down.

Sid Meierâ€™s CivilizationÂ® VI Anthology is a beautifully designed and fun game that offers hours of entertainment for fans of the series. With its excellent graphics, intricate mechanics, and varied game-play options, this game is sure to provide an enjoyable experience for players.

One of the most impressive aspects of the game is its stunning visual design. The landscapes are intricately detailed, and the cities are beautifully rendered, making the game a joy to explore. The art style is colorful and vibrant, truly capturing the spirit of exploration and discovery that is at the heart of the Civilization series.

The game's design is also top-notch. The mechanics of the game are complex, but they are presented in a way that is easy to understand and follow. The game provides a variety of options for players to explore, from diplomacy and trade to warfare and cultural development. The game's technology tree is vast, providing players with a sense of progression and achievement as they advance through the ages.

While the game is undeniably fun to play, it does have its drawbacks. The limited multiplayer support is a significant issue, as the game's multiplayer mode has limited stability. This can be disappointing for players who enjoy playing with larger groups of people. Additionally, there are occasional issues with multiplayer connections, which can disrupt the flow of the game.

Another drawback of the game is the lack of online features. While players can connect with other players through the multiplayer mode, there are no online features such as leader-boards or matchmaking. This can make it difficult for players to find other players to play with and can limit the social aspect of the game.

Perhaps the most significant drawback of the game is the mindless AI. While the game's AI is intelligent and capable of making smart decisions, it is not as formidable as it should be. The game's enemies are not aggressive or strategic enough, and they often make decisions that are easy to predict. This makes the game less challenging and can diminish the sense of accomplishment that players feel when they win.

Despite these issues, Sid Meierâ€™s CivilizationÂ® VI Anthology is an excellent game that is sure to please fans of the series. The game's beautiful design and fun game-play make it an enjoyable experience for players. The game's single-player mode is particularly engaging, providing players with a deep and immersive experience that will keep them coming back for more.

In conclusion, Sid Meierâ€™s CivilizationÂ® VI Anthology is a well-designed and enjoyable game that has a few flaws. The game's limited multiplayer support, multiplayer connection issues, lack of online features, and mindless AI may be disappointing for some players. However, the game's stunning visuals, complex mechanics, and varied game-play options make it a must-play for fans of the series. Despite its flaws, Sid Meierâ€™s CivilizationÂ® VI Anthology is a game that is sure to provide hours of entertainment for players of all skill levels.

Not my type of game, but very well-made, so I recommend it, especially if you are interested in strategy games. At least but the Platinum Edition though, which includes two game-changing (no pun intended) expansion packs (Rise and Fall, Gathering Storm).

For those who are still on the fence, beware that the game has a really steep learning curve due to the enormous number of components inside (a long list of civilisations, districts, buildings, wonders, units, civics, technologies, which has its own cost and benefit). In addition, a game takes quite a long time (~10 hours for a normal speed game). To fully enjoy this title, my conservative estimate is that one has to invest one hundred hours to just get familiar with most contents. So, this game is not for casual players who are looking for an easy-to-pick-up title that they can occasionally have several hours of fun.

As someone who had never played any of the Civilization games before I went into this with the thought that it would be similar to those city builder mobile games (Clash of Clans, Dragon City & The Simspons: Tapped out) from the 2010s, while there are many similarities to those in Civ 6, there are also quite a few differences. My favourite being that once you purchase the game you aren't bombarded by micro-transactions. I decided to pick this game up because I saw the crazy 90% discount and had heard good things about it. Whilst I don't see myself touching this game again, I easily got my $10 worth just going through the tutorial world anyway.

6/10 Overall

i don't know how anyone could say, "oh yea, I love this game," holy crap. I mean I like a strategy game as much as the next guy. I mean obviously right, I bought this one, unfortunately. But I generally when one drops you off right at the beginning, you click, "no, I've never played this game before, yea, go ahead and show me how this one works," you see a hexagonal grid across the screen, one guy or group or something standing there, next to another something, group I assume and just icons covering the screen, holy crap, ok we're planning on explaining what this is I'm looking at, or better yet, maybe what you would like me to do with them? Apparently not. So you can just start clicking things, if you want, they do have an insanely long encyclopedia you can open for literally every single thing you can click on.

And don't get me wrong, I'm sure if you have a week or so to spend reading every random bit of information you click on, and I say random because, you just ASSUME what it was you just clicked on is even relevant to whatever you need to be focused on, in that particular moment. Because you did select the option to give me this "tutorial" you guys been bragging about so, it stands to reason that eventually it's going to start, right? I mean, that is a crap load of apparent options for each little icon. And I was clicking away with no clue if any of it was even right or not. great game, totally worth it over its predecessors for being more rich in features and rounded, see more below. I got around to buy all of it, even the arguably unnecessary DLCs for me and the wive (on a good discount, though), maybe to satisfy my inner hunter/gatherer. We like to play on map size: large, difficulty: immortal, random leader each. Recently, we discovered the extended eras mod:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2123444827

Basically, research and cultural progress on marathon speed while production remains standard speed. This way, the end game stays more interesting. Without the mod, you barely get to enjoy infantry, tanks and airplanes because technological progress is just too fast. The mod extends the fun without the weirdness of marathon speed in vanilla.

I think Civ IV introduced religion, but they didn't dare to put distinguishing features into those, at the time. Civ V introduced hexagons and the one-unit-per-tile principle, both great additions. Civ VI introduced **districts**, the full-blown loyalty mechanism (in one of the add-ons), the independent tree of cultural progress (civ V had something quite similar, though), an unparalleled number of leaders with actual distinct characteristics and corresponding play-style. Also Civ VI has great mechanics for Great People and gives use to faith points even if you don't care for religion in your game.

Somewhere between Civ III and VI they turned diplomacy with AI players into something interesting. Probably the most important changes happened in Civ VI. The different ways to declare war in order to avoid being the bad guy are a great model of real international politics: Declaring war without properly denouncing the other nation in due time? You are a war criminal. - Oh! You denounced them 5 turns ago? My bad, let's kill the bad guy together.

I don't know which part of the series introduced aircraft carriers - maybe they were around since always. It is still my personal highlight to produce these in order to bomb cities at the other end of the world and conquer them. The logistics of it accurately reflect some real-life modern warfare.

All in all, Civ in its latest version remains the genre-defining game. I never tried Humankind, but its aggregated reviews amount only to "mixed", so I haven't yet bothered to check it out.

(I will also for ever remember the mod "Fall from heaven" for Civ IV ... just spectacular. So in terms of mods and add-ons, technically Civ VI hasn't even reached its full potential)

[h1]Sid Meier's Civilization VI: Unleash Your Inner Leader in the Epic Saga of Civilization[/h1]

[quote=author]Embark on a journey through time and build your own empire in Sid Meier's Civilization VI. With its intricate strategy, captivating historical depth, and addictive gameplay, this is more than just a gameâ€”it's a grand civilization-building adventure![/quote]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
Sid Meier's Civilization VI, developed by Firaxis Games, is the latest installment in the acclaimed Civilization series. From humble beginnings to world domination, this turn-based strategy game challenges you to lead your civilization through the ages. Dive into a meticulously crafted world where every decision shapes the course of history.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Graphics and Artistry[/h2]
Civilization VI brings history to life with its visually stunning art style. The game features vibrant landscapes, detailed cityscapes, and animated leaders that reflect the diverse cultures represented. The attention to historical accuracy is evident, creating an immersive experience that captures the essence of each era.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Strategic Gameplay[/h2]
The heart of Civilization VI lies in its deep and strategic gameplay. From choosing your civilization's leader to managing resources, diplomacy, and warfare, every decision has far-reaching consequences. The addition of unstacked cities and districts introduces new layers of strategy, making city planning a crucial element in your quest for dominance.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Cultural and Scientific Progress[/h2]
One of Civilization VI's standout features is the emphasis on cultural and scientific development. The Civics and Technology trees have been redesigned to provide more meaningful choices, allowing players to tailor their civilizations to their preferred playstyles. Witness the cultural and scientific evolution of your society as you advance through the ages.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Diplomacy and Alliances[/h2]
Navigate the complex web of international relations as you interact with AI leaders or other players. Diplomacy in Civilization VI is nuanced and dynamic, with alliances, trade agreements, and negotiations shaping the geopolitical landscape. Forge alliances or engage in cunning diplomacy to achieve your goals, but beware of the ever-changing political climate.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Wonders of the World[/h2]
Civilization VI showcases iconic Wonders of the World, each with unique bonuses and historical significance. From the Pyramids to the Eiffel Tower, constructing these wonders not only bolsters your civilization but also adds a visual spectacle to your expanding empire. The race to build wonders becomes a competitive and strategic element of the game.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Expansions and DLCs[/h2]
Firaxis Games continues to enrich the Civilization VI experience with expansions and DLCs that introduce new civilizations, leaders, and game mechanics. These additions not only keep the game fresh but also deepen its replayability, providing players with new challenges and opportunities to explore.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Modding Community[/h2]
Civilization VI embraces the creativity of its community through robust modding support. The Steam Workshop is a treasure trove of user-generated content, offering everything from new civilizations and leaders to custom scenarios and game-changing mods. The modding community ensures that Civilization VI remains a dynamic and evolving experience.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a triumph in the strategy genre, offering a rich and immersive experience that appeals to both history enthusiasts and strategic masterminds. With its visually captivating design, deep gameplay mechanics, and a wealth of content through expansions and mods, Civilization VI stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of the Civilization series.

[quote=author]Lead your people to greatness, build wonders, and leave an indelible mark on the annals of history in Sid Meier's Civilization VI![/quote]

Civ VI, a monster of a game, absolute beast in scale and execution, but not perfect.... 

Problems will only become apparent after more than a hundred hours into the game. To sum up, seasoned veterans will lament how the world seed and AI progression delivers a somewhat on-rails experience, meaning creativity is sometimes stifled because that's not how the game wants you to play and theyve already planned for this in the scripting and the seed generation. 

Where you start every game has already been calculated by seed balancing to ensure equal strengths over the course of the game so sometimes its noticable when you veer of that track how the game limits you. So trying to settle in lands 'you're not supposed to' can make unrealistic barbarian hostility, or settling near a natural wonder far from your capital will make other civs hostile to you, or just accidently roaming the seas and uncovering land that is good for settling where the AI could have settled but have not yet but would give you an advantage to settle there will cause the AI to aggressively settle there like their maps show where you've explored. Many things like that......

Overall a very accomplished title in the series, yet one hopes the developers dont fall over each other trying to deliver a balanced consensus of a game as Civ Vi represents an evolution of the formula clearly taking inspirations from the feedback from the game and its players over time, lest it become contrived in its purposes and not find its roots in being a groundbreaking title.

"Civilization 6" enhances the classic strategy game series with new ways to engage with the world. Players can expand their empires across the map, advance their culture, and compete against history's greatest leaders. With dynamic diplomacy and diverse tactics for victory, each session offers unique challenges. The game's intricate city planning and complex geopolitics add depth. However, its AI can be inconsistent, and multiplayer has some connectivity issues. Overall, "Civ 6" offers a rich, customizable experience for strategy enthusiasts, though it might be complex for newcomers to the genre.

I've been playing Civilization since the original in 1990 on a 286 machine. I've played every version extensively, Although this is not my favorite, it is fun and entertaining.

I really wanted to like this game, as I've been a Civ fan since Civ 1 came out during my college days. Maybe I'm an old, impossible to please, curmudgeonly gamer now, maybe I'm no longer the target audience, but in my opinion, the big changes made in Civ 6 have made the game less enjoyable overall. A couple of examples that come to mind after a dozen hours of gameplay: I could overlook the overly bright colors and cartoonish visuals if the UI was better organized, but I find the explored-but-not-currently-in-view areas are harder to discern than the fog of war style of the predecessors. Civ 6's civilopedia is written in a style that is less scholarly, more cynical, and several clicks away to find the entry to the technology you just gained. It doesn't resonate well with me. The card system of civic policies is busy and gets in the way of actual gameplay, because new ones are made available at such a rapid pace.

I play Civ to relax, but playing Civ 6 feels like a management sim. Maybe I'll pick it up again after someone's had the chance to mod some fun back into it.

Update: After a few hundred hours' playtime I've gotten used to all of the above and have changed my recommendation.

*editing in 2021*

So I wanted to update this and switch it to a thumbs up, they have since fixed whatever multiplayer bug was causing so many crashes in multiplayer as I talk about in the older negative review below.  Now that it doesn't crash every single multiplayer run...it is great.  It does still sometimes have desyncs but they are rare and dont cause a loss of a turn or a crash.  Basically only if it is a huge map and late game or something along with the internet being awful.  Unfortunate it took until basically this last year to actually get fully playable but I guess better late than never.  Here is hoping civ 7 doesn't have that problem.


( old review in 2019)

Love these games.  This one is no different.  The expansions lean into it even more.  Things are typical civ.  It is really turning into a great game.  However, this game getting a ton less play time.  Why?  Well it does this damned desync thing no matter what me and my civ partner try.  Lan, internet, full screen, windowed, graphics up, graphics down, doesn't matter.  If it doesn't desync and waste a ton of time.  Then it tends to crash.  Less for me really.  I can do solo games no problem but in multi someone seems to be desynced or crashing all the time.  Sometimes you can get a game to keep going if it is small or tiny map.  This isn't a baby game.  We are now on the 2nd major content release for the 6th game.  It can't be crashing in multi.  Across multiple computer builds too.  Its not an uncommon problem.

So ya know.  Still fun but careful if you want to play with friends cause it is going to be a hassle.  Always civ 5 to play though.

Either way a civ game getting a not recommended from me is crazy but I expend most of my hours playing with a small section of friends and it is a problem.  It is at 1/3 played time from civ 5.

It is a shame how such a great game series could be ruined. Civ6 game play is very slow, lots of clicking, lots of micromanagement. There are lots of events, that are silly and takes some time. The worst is that after 10+ hours of gaming I have bunch of cities, that does not have what to produce. It is very difficult to concur another city, and it is difficult in a boring way. I regret I bought it and hope Civ7 will be better.

I like every Civ game but still waited until Anthology was on sale for this one. I do not want to know what this game was like in its original version but it is not worth buying even with all the addons. If there were no other Civ games this one might be ok but in comparison it feels like half a game.

One major issue is the bonuses you acquire throughout the game. They are as impactful as the bonuses on weapons in an MMORPG. Get one extra gold on full moons if the name of the building starts with an "a" and does not give you more than three other bonuses... Even though this should be a beginner's problem it does not get better with more hours of gameplay. Just build whatever you like and hope that the bonuses somehow add up in combination with the surroundings you discover and the decisions you make.

I missed a lot of features from earlier games but founding new cities has always been a key concept from my point of view. Unfortunately founding new cities is reduced to a handful due to missing space. To develop a big city in Civ6 you need a lot of space. But even on a huge map with reduced number of city states and AIs there is very little space from the beginning.

I could add many more details but to summarize it - I prefer the previous Civs and this one is closer (and inferior) to Age of Wonders.

Do not play this game if you are remotely intelligent, or interested in maps, history, culture, religion, science, politics, economics, art, literature, architecture, basically humanity in general. Also don't play if you like war games with complex unit development and tactics. It will steal your life away, You will keep wanting to go "one more turn" and then suddenly realize it is already 4:00am and the sun is about to rise. It even has the potential to ruin your life. Some positives: Many concepts like the loyalty system, governors, and revamped Religion and Great Person systems seem well thought out and an improvement from previous games. Districts and Governors give you greater control over the map and customization/specialization for your cities, and playing wide is much less punishing than Civ V, so filling up the map or grabbing resources with a settler don't tank your game.

That said, here is why this review is negative.
The game has had consistent "support" in the form of DLCs (some of which are free, to be fair) since release, but:

[b]a) Core functionality I expected, that prompted me to buy the game in the first place, is still missing.[/b]

I bought this game so I could relax and play it on the couch, with a controller. It was a headache to get it working on controller + TV for various reasons (no controller support, UI scaling is locked at 1080p, etc) despite fact that there are actual ports for all major consoles. There's no crossplay, so even if I had a console version I could not play with people on PC. This game was heavily advertised alongside the Steam Controller, which I own, but does not have real controller support. I eventually just gave up trying to use it as a couch game. It's honestly infuriating that console ports exist but basic controller UI is totally unavailable in the PC version.

[b]b) The game is unstable when run with all content enabled, because it attempts to load [i]everything[/i] in the game rather than just what is actively being used.[/b]

The game engine has a limit to the number of assets that can be loaded. It doesn't matter if those assets are actually [i]used[/i], if too many packages are enabled it will crash as soon as you launch a new game. I like to play with mods, and even just a few UI mods will now reliably crash the game because they have pumped so many DLCs into it without bothering to fix the core engine - meaning the game itself is near its own asset limit now. Of course you can disable DLCs, but I really shouldn't have to disabled paid content just to add a few units or change a few textures.

Game punishes you for trying to take military path to victory. If you decide to conquer your opponents by force that means building siege units, range units, melee units and you need a lot. While you do all this your opponents double down on economy, technology, culture and religion. All these traits lead can lead to victory. In conclusion while you fight another opponent you just lose because you are never going to make it in time. If you pick the winning condition to be only military conquest it becomes the most dull and boring game. The AI in this game is god awful no matter what difficulty you pick. Enemy units will keep going close to your fortress and hit random buildings but not focus on the unit that is actually damaging them. I got declared war on me multiple times where the enemy did not bother to bring any siege units and the fights were completely one sided and It was an effortless win.

If you decide to pick any other traits like technology, culture or religion it becomes a building simulator where you just build and press end turn. 

Oh and If you want to play campaign, think again there is none. Only skirmish vs terribly programmed AI.
Save your time and money, I regret spending any time on this and the few euros I spent. Overall a very bad experience.

As someone who is relatively inexperienced in playing games like Sid Meier's Civilization VI, I have found the experience to be quite enjoyable. Although I haven't had much hands-on experience myself, I have observed others playing the game on several occasions. It is a game that can easily occupy a few hours of your time, as there is always something new to discover and explore.

One of the things that I appreciate about Sid Meier's Civilization VI is how simple it is to pick up the basics. The game provides a tutorial mode that guides you through the initial steps, making it easy for beginners to understand the mechanics and objectives. This allows newcomers like myself to dive right into the game and start having fun, even without prior experience.

While it is true that there is a lot more to learn in order to take the game to the next level, this does not diminish the enjoyment that can be found by just grasping the basics. There are numerous strategies and tactics to master, different civilizations to play as, and various victory conditions to achieve. This depth and complexity add layers of challenge and excitement to the gameplay, keeping players engaged and wanting to explore more.

Even if you can't dedicate a significant amount of time to learning every aspect of the game, you can still find enjoyment in Sid Meier's Civilization VI by simply grasping the basics. The game offers different difficulty levels, allowing players to adjust the challenge according to their skill level and available time. Whether you have just a few minutes or a few hours to spare, you can still have a fulfilling gaming experience by focusing on the fundamentals.

In conclusion, while I may be relatively inexperienced in playing games like Sid Meier's Civilization VI, I have found it to be an enjoyable and immersive experience. The game is easy to pick up and provides hours of entertainment. There is certainly more to learn in order to take your gameplay to the next level, but even if you only grasp the basics, you can still find enjoyment and fulfillment in playing this captivating strategy game.

I have no idea what the hype is about this very slow and laborious game. It's easy to win, in theory, But the end is crazy slow too. I've got fleets of equipment including rockets and bombers at the top of the tech tree, yet it takes 4 or 5 years/rounds to take a city full of musket wielding men? In theory I was holding on to build a nuke, but it takes dozens and dozens of rounds, because you can't ever group production of cities, and nor can a city of population 20+ produce two things at once - not a hope of having a sewer and an infantryman, despite the huge city!
It really is showing it's age, and how are there still silly bugs after all these years of dev work and updates and no "undo" for when the graphics show your units are miles apart and you click on the wrong one? Luckily, there's only a 2 minute wait(!) as the game reloads off your SSD... (And play with "autosave" after each turn, for when the routing goes screwy! Or your bombing run targets the empty hex next to your target city!)
Anyway, it was worth the Â£5 I guess - time did fly playing it, at first, before it dragged.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This is an INCREDIBLE game!
This is not an over-exaggeration. Released on many different platforms, the devs have made a game accessible for everyone without it being a cheap money grab without a care for graphics, updates or even the player base.
The graphics are exceptional, little unlock cinematics, watch your troops fight. Life is in every moment in this game.
The music is brilliant, ambient for relaxing play but enough to engage and not be annoying.
The game play is on another level: so many intricacies and areas to master without being overwhelming to a new player. The tutorial allows you to get straight into the game, starting from the beginning. Researching and building is realistic while maintaining a turn based aesthetic.
I bought the Anthology Bundle, allowing full access to all DLCs, I would usually expect them to be awful however I found that the DLCs unlocked the entire game, providing a better experience. Not to mention new ways to win and new leaders to experience. [Although there is no Napoleon :( ]

Overall, this game is worth it for hours of fun, games take a meaningful amount of time (I spent 30 hrs on one game) however this time doesn't drag on. Every minute is full of fun and pleasure from this game.

10/10, Five stars. Would recommend.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

[b]Let me see what I can say about this game except launcher and exceptionally terrible intro sound...[/b]

Why my great civilization sending missions to Mars doesn't have space to store paintings?

Why it takes hundreds of years to build a district?

Why are cities (and districts) so disproportionally huge comparing to world map?

Why my huge mega-city can't build a new district on or work the 4th tile [which obviously belongs to it]? Yet how do you get resources from it if nobody works it??

Why you can't move districts? How is oil extracted from under your university?

Why are barbarians having technologies which take civilizations hundreds of years of research? Where do they get oil from to have infantry?

Why you can raze cities but can't raze districts?

Why can't you just remove districts you haven't discovered yet from captured cities?

Why you can't trade territories with other civs (e.g. buy a tile from them)?

Why liberating (restoring) a city-state suddenly moves your unites from its borders (normally closer to the position of your enemy - the one you liberated it from)? Same for protectorate war and enemy units.

Why your great people can live for hundreds/thousands years? Why you can send them clearing barbarian outposts? (I had Homer clear not one but two - with help obviously).
Why is there no option to ask my alliance partner not to attack my vassal with a ton of envoys?

Why you can't repair improvements of your alliance partners?

Why you can't give a city of your enemy to your alliance partner?

Why you can't produce earlier military units in later eras (if tight on gold or lack resources)?

Why cost of building stuff increases with each era? It's supposed to be the other way.

Why you can't trade food within your own empire (without "traders" mechanics with stupid limit - I just wanna send some food from my huge capital to my little town in taiga without crippling my international trade)?

Why can't your units pass through city center of friendly civilization (example: Istanbul on Mediterranean TSL blocking passage from Asia to Europe)?

Why can't your apostle [as Kongo] "heal and repair" in Holy Sites of his religion?

[b]UPD:[/b]

Why is AI so bad that you can easily beat Prince on Standard map with only one city? (Obviously can be done on harder difficulties on smaller maps).

Why are there 8 (eight) difficulties in this game with only 1-3 of them playable (under certain conditions)?

Why do you have to invent challenging ways to play this game because of how AI sucks?
Seriously, why-why-why is AI is so outstandingly bad? You can't make worse AI even if you try.

Why is the game after 10 years of development still so lacking in hotkeys department? Hotkey for yields, hello? (I ended up making one in Autohotkey, of course).

Why isn't there a way to display/sort list of cities with production - i.e., collapsable yields list, without details per building.

Why isn't there a proper list of units (technically there is a very awkward one)?

Why isn't there an option to mute certain notifications?
How about stopping AI bothering you with certain type of trades?
How about auto-extending option for trade routes and alliances?

Why can't you open borders with city-states in early game (maybe for a fee)?

Why is AI luxury resource buying price like 10 times higher than his selling price? Sell one resource for 300 gold and buy another for 30. It's broken. The "professional" strategy to settle on luxury and sell it to AI is straight broken BS and should be patched out.

Why disasters hurt military units but do not hurt civilians?

Why you can't kill civilians with ranged fire (war crime and diplomatic penalty)?

Why captured city-states don't go back to city-state status after another civ loses them on loyalty and you refuse them?

Why are there no options to auto-extend friendships and deals?

Why isn't neutralized governor re-assigned to his city automatically?

Why so much tedious micromanagement?


And, about that intro:
Why is its sound in my earphones (!) so loud that it woke up my girlfriend?

Otherwise it's not a bad game.

The 2k Launcher doesn't support hidipi displays and is an annoying pointless hindrance. The launcher is the sole reason I'm denouncing the game. The launcher isn't part of the outdated Linux/Mac Aspyr versions...

I managed to bypass it by using the following launch option:

```
eval $( echo "%command%" | sed "s/2KLauncher\/LauncherPatcher.exe'.*/Base\/Binaries\/Win64Steam\/CivilizationVI_DX12'/" )
```

---

The Aspyr Linux/Mac version is out of date and won't work with the saves from the much newer SteamPlay version... make sure to force enable SteamPlay Proton 8 (latest). It was extremely stable in my experience playing on a Chromebook with an i5-1540P.

Unfortunately this means downloading another 10GB package for me... not ideal. On the flip side the Android version is extremely unstable and outdated... barely playable as it crashes every every other turn late game... it's still glorious on foldables.

Pros...tons of civs to play, good DLCs, different strategies to win, an excellent modding community. Pick the game up when there is a sale. You will get tons of playtime out of this game.

Cons....of course all games have them. This game does suffer from issues with multiplayer and some tedium once you have started to snowball in the game, but winning feels all too good after you have sent your armies to conquer the world.

Civilization 6 may not be worth the full $60 price tag, but for the $8 I paid, it's an absolute steal. I can't say anything bad about it, except for some minor glitches. Playing with friends adds an extra layer of enjoyment, making the overall experience nothing short of addictive.

Updated review: I changed my review to not recommended because the multiplayer works only intermittently. Every single game in my Steam library can be played with friends, with the exception of this game. This is the only game that doesn't work. I've spent probably hundreds of hours trying to work around the de-sync issues to play with friends. The netcode is just so unbelievably poor. It's so unacceptable for a game that's commercialized as well as this one has. I know of no other game that works as poorly as this one. I expect they will never fix it now, they have had so long and the quality of the matchmaking & netcode is worse than any other digital experience I know of.

Original review:

I seriously believe this is one of the best games (and series) of all time. However, it would be nice if it wasn't also vying for "most crash-y game of all time".

I swear nobody complained about this game being unstable a few years back - the developers seems to have severely damaged the games stability in the meanwhile, as you'll see many recent reviews here mentioning the unplayability. 

That's what's so frustrating. It's not unplayable because the systems within the game are so badly flawed, it's simply that it's so unstable that you might not actually be able to play at all. I can't remember having ever played a game that crashes as much as this one does.

I always imagine they must have like two people handling this entire game's development. I can just see them saying: 

"yeah we know dude, we're doing everything we can to improve it. Unfortunately management hasn't allocated time for bug fixes. Looks like we're gonna be creating things that nobody asked for like vampires and witches for years to come." That content would be appropriate on the assumption they'd taken care of stability and balance issues, which they definitely haven't.

Why this game is awesome:
- While the single player is entertaining and great for learning, once you do multiplayer with folks you know IRL you won't be able to go back to single player. The internal politics of the game feel surprisingly 'real', as you decide whether to work collaboratively, work against, or deceive the other people your playing with. Nothing can make my heart pound quite like trying to bullshit somebody that you pose no threat, when your in fact breaking the bank on stealth bombers and tanks to come raze their cities in short order. It's the actual word-by-word discussion over voice chat that makes the political component of this game so riveting. This game has literally had me sweating in my seat and certain moments in time. Knowing that they're most likely up to something nefarious too adds to the excitement. 

It's this dynamic I've described above that really captures why this game hits you so much harder than most others out there. So many ways to collaborate. So many ways to deceive. It's funny to think that this digital board game could really get your heart racing, but it does! Not so much for singleplayer, but against other humans absolutely. When you win, MAN IT FEELS GOOD. And when you lose, it hurts more than in other video games.

Things they need to improve:

I don't want a damn piece of content from 2k other than bug fixes. The stuff they're coming out with is like Toyota giving you a hot wheels to help out with your broken car. Sure it's cute but I need my car to work alright before I'm interested in mundane crap like that. 

Not to mention, 2k has a pretty solid anti-consumer reputation. The promoted the hell out of Civ 5's last expansion, and then damn near followed up the next week with, "Actually Civ 6 is gonna be here soon!". Super scammy behavior. They knew nobody would buy the expansion if they announced Civ 6 first. I'm sure they won't be behaving like that in the future right?

Of course they will!! you thought this game was for you?? It's for the 2k shareholders! While the game has gone both downhill and uphill since launch, take-two interactive stock is up 251.5% since launch! This would explain a thing or two.

The internal balance of the game is a bit off too. Fortunately they give you tools to select the exact city states & natural wonders in your game, which is where a lot of the balance issues lie. Not to mention, the math often doesn't add up. The Nan Madol city state is supposed to provide +2 culture for each district you have on a lake or coast tile, yet I've seen it provide more than twice as much as that per district. It really breaks the game because it's so unusually powerful.

They should be addressing balance and stability! Not coming up with new game modes and artsy crap. So far they've skated by with their general crappiness, probably due to the decades worth of momentum behind the civilization franchise, which they're benefitting so much from. As much as I love this game, it's hard to be a fan knowing that they've most likely already committed to releasing Civ 7 as an uncomplete game, for which they will then launch a $39.99 expansion, which will include absolutely essential game mechanics, rather than plain old 'content', so that you end up paying $100 grand total for the game.

Ultimately, I'm neutral on this game. I can't wholeheartedly reccomend it due to their shady business practices and the instability of the game, yet it's also my favorite game :/

Sid Meier's Civilization VI is the latest installment in the beloved, long-running 4X turn-based strategy franchise. As with previous Civilization games, the objective is to grow a fledgling civilization into a dominant world power across multiple eras of human history. This newest entry enhances the addictive gameplay loop the series is known for with smart improvements under the hood and visually stunning new animations, landscapes, and stylized leaders that bring your empire to life.

Longtime fans will appreciate the mechanical refinements and additional gameplay possibilities introduced in Civilization VI. City building in particular has been overhauled, with housing limits and new district system that present more interesting strategic choices when planning your urban sprawl. Governments now provide powerful policy bonuses that can significantly shift playstyles. All of this added complexity layers onto the franchise's signature addictive loop of exploring the map, expanding your empire, exploiting resources, and exterminating rivals.

Visually, Civilization has never looked better. The new tile-based map creates an eye-popping landscape of lush forests, arid deserts, and rolling hills that transition beautifully across seasons and eras. The colorful new leader animation styles infuse the iconic figures of history with warmth and personality. The user interface has also been cleaned up and made more readable. The polished new visuals combined with an upbeat original soundtrack make this Civ game extremely immersive and enjoyable to play for hours on end.

With improved visuals, refinements under the hood, and additional replay value from a strong selection of new civilizations and leaders, Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a must-have for veteran fans and an excellent entry point for newcomers to one of gaming's most storied franchises. While not revolutionary, it is a methodical, well-crafted evolution for the series that will provide hundreds of hours of empire-building enjoyment. This is quite possibly the most addictive Civilization game yet.

CIV 6 is an educative game, where you can learn much about the world and history. The most interesting facts I got to know by playing:
- Adelaide was founded in 800 AD directly south of Mount Fuji
- SheepHerder Bob was the first scout and explorer to circumnavigate the world in 150 BC, funded by the leader Teddy Roosevelt
- The first ever trade route was established between the Aztec Empire and China
- Shortly after Vivaldi wrote the Four Seasons in Ulaanbaatar, the Mongols entered a golden era
- Completing the Manhattan Project was a big turning point for the Maori, allowing them to build their first nuclear device in 1710
-  The Inca came close to become a world-leading force by colonizing another planet but losing their last city  to Korea prevented this.
