So far compared to previous civs I have liked this one the least. Tile strategy is crucial before you even have an understanding of the implications in the game? This is to me more like a civ game for those obsessed with the algebra of perfect city planning and the luck of not being landlocked and surrounded by the default raging barbarians. After a decent amount of play time it feels the game is balanced to constantly hinder and hold you back. Firaxis I play video games to excape that feeling from my career, I am sorely disappointed in this rendition of the civ franchise.

That being said slowly over time balance changes have made it more tolerable. You still must play only the hand you didn't know you were dealt until mid-game, so e.g. if you had early resources that made science a winning strategy but it turns out the game decided to bless you in theology you better redirect your momentum lest you have a medocre mid-late game. Then there are the times you "win" by diplomacy, what a sham. This one needs rethinking IMHO. I turn it off for better gameplay. 

Overall I think its just trying to be too many mechanics at once out of balance with each other. An amazing game were it not for all of those balance issues.

I know I am going to catch a lot of flack for this, but I don't care. I am not exactly a newcomer to the series, having played both 4 and 5, but I am also admitedly not an expert.

That said, CIV 6 is needlessly complicated and the mechanics depressingly poorly explained. Each game feels like a chore instead of fun. I do not know what to do in most of the situations and the game does not tell me - having to read a civpedia or whatever instead of having a pop up with a few lines explaining it, without breaking the flow of the game is just poor game developing in my opinion and feels like artificially padding the game time.

The first few times I played this game I got overwhelmed by barbarian forces with more military stregth than any of the civs present in the game sessions. It was only after searching the Internet that I found out that, if you don't kill barbarian scouts, the game makes it its priority to overwhelm your cities with invading forces. This was not something the game explained to me or, at the very least, was a critical part of gameplay that was so poorly presented I managed to miss it. I had to LOOK IT UP ON THE INTERNET. Other Civs declare war on me from across the map without any obvious reason, etc. Yes I am sure there are perfectly good mechanics/reasons for that to happen. The point is that nothing is explained to me. I do not pretend that the previous games in the series were masterpieces at launch but at least I never felt like I was floundering for not having the game taught to me.

I also do not like the UI. The buttons are too small and not (to me) immediately obvious and many of the options are hidden from view. It's just more work in what should be fun.

Ultimately I guess I must accept that this newer entry just isn't for me. I do not find this game fun, I do not play games to have to study a PhD in order to play them, and as such cannot recommend it.

The game overall is pretty good. It has numerous weakpoints and strongpoints.

Strongpoints: 
1. It really isn't boring, you are always going to think "just one more turn"
2. There is a decent attempt to present different cultures
3. It has strategy elements 

Weakpoints:
1. The age/tech progression is absurdly fast. You go from ancient to pre-modern weaponry way too fast
2. The balance between playing wide/tall is clearly in favor of wide, which makes the "strategy of civ building" to be how many settlers can you produce?
3. While there is an effort to portray different cultures. 1 unit/building in a specific age is not enough. 
4. There is no diplomacy game. (EU4/Imperator has a fleshed out diplomacy game)
5. Units can't be produced alongside building. This means you can only focus on city building or unit building. 
6. The game actively disincentivise conquest/expansion and eco focus games with the progressive increment costs. 

In essence the game is extremelly fun in the early stages up to the mid-game but after that point it is a lot less interesting. 

Overall this is a great game for a casual strategy gamer. The game itselft is wide but has little to no depth. That's all.

Overall would recommend it as it is a good game. They really need to add the dlcs to the base game since entry for new players costs a rediculous amount of money right now....

I wholeheartedly recommend Civilization VI; it stands as a phenomenal game that has consistently provided me with enjoyable experiences over the years. The only minor critique I have pertains to the combat aspect, but when considering the overall package, this game deserves a solid 10 out of 10.

What truly sets Civilization VI apart is its city-building mechanics, which have been refined to perfection. The political intricacies add depth, making every decision feel impactful. It's an ideal title for those seeking a relaxing night, a chance to immerse themselves in the art of nation-building.

The game grants you the power to shape a civilization from its infancy, fostering expansion and growth. While the late game may seem to progress a bit too swiftly, reaching the later ages can bring a sense of abruptness. Nevertheless, the game's overall excellence overshadows this minor pacing concern.

Civilization VI provides an ideal environment for unwinding, allowing players to kick back and enjoy the process of leading a nation to greatness. The gameplay, from societies to characters and factions, covers all aspects one would desire in a civilization-building game.

Moreover, the game strikes a perfect balance between simplicity and complexity. While some may find certain aspects a tad straightforward, this streamlined approach enhances engagement. A more complex game might risk becoming tedious, but Civilization VI keeps you hooked with its elegant simplicity.

In my years of playing, I've discovered that Civilization VI is the go-to title for a captivating and immersive experience. Whether you're starting a new civilization or navigating through late-game eras, the game consistently delivers satisfaction.

To those contemplating purchasing Civilization VI, don't hesitate. It's an absolute gem that offers a well-rounded gaming experience. Feel free to reach out; I'm always eager to welcome new players into my world. As we await the next iteration, I can confidently say that Civilization VI is a must-try for strategy enthusiasts, and I'm genuinely excited about what the future holds for this fantastic series.

Overall a great game that's very enjoyable.  Building an empire feels very satisfying and there is a lot of depth that isn't immediately apparent, such that I am still learning new things about how game mechanics work despite being hundreds of hours deep in the game.  In some ways this might be seen as a bad thing in that it signifies there isn't a lot of transparency in the game on how things work, but that's not the case for the most part.  For the most part it's just that there are so many things to do that until you look each one up in the in-game civilopedia you only understand the basic concepts and not the behind-the-scenes mechanics.


There are some things I would love to see improved in the next iteration, like combat.  Especially the way simultaneous-turn multiplayer combat is handled.  Right now in multiplayer it's kind of a click-fest to see who attacks with their units faster.  I can empathize with the devs because it's hard to come up with a perfect way to fix this.  When a combat starts, do you just kind of pause the game for everyone and wait for all units on either side to take turns making attacks?  That wouldn't be fun for players not in combat.  But if you allow players to just attack each other at full speed in real-time, it creates an element of a real-time-strategy game that feels out of place given that this game is turn-based.  My idea for this would be to just adjust the way that combat works to give less of an attacker's advantage except in the most extreme circumstances.  For example, if a slinger attacks a warrior, the warrior shouldn't just sit there and lose half its health.  They should engage each other simultaneously so it doesn't matter if the player with the warrior clicked first or the player with the slinger clicked first.  The only times this wouldn't be the case is when attacking from more than 1 range, such as an archer 2 hexes away, in which case having a melee attacker run all the way across 2 hexes wouldn't make sense and some advantage should go to the player that is using range.  That being said, if an archer is attacking something that can attack back like another archer, they should simultaneously attack each other whenever either player attacks so that it's more fair and isn't just "who clicked first" or "who is host and has less delay."

But other than the multiplayer combat issues and some minor multiplayer desync issues the game is a blast

Previously I would have recommended this game wholeheatedly, as you can tell from my wild playtime, but the 2K Launcher has developed a very nasty bug that causes it to think you don't actually own the game. For other Firaxis games like Midnight Suns or XCOM2 this isn't a problem because you can either bypass the terrible launcher (Midnight Suns) or there are community-made alternatives (XCOM2), but the game binary for Civ6 has been lobotomized so that it now checks for LauncherPatcher.exe, which in turn searches for and runs the 2K Launcher, only allowing the game to launch if the Civ6 executable is launched via the 2K Launcher itself. This means that previous methods of bypassing the 2K Launcher, such as directly launching the game executable, using a launch option in Steam properties, or using the old LaunchPad launcher no longer work.
This also means that if, for example, 2K stops supporting the game, you will no longer be able to play the game as their launcher will not validate your ownership of the game; it also means that you cannot play Civ 6 offline at all. This is actually a particular kind of civil crime known as 'defrauding', which is waived by the EULA basically saying that "you agree that you don't actually own the software you purchased and we can revoke your ability to use the software at any time", but EULAs are rarely tested in court because individuals don't have the power to test large corporations and class action suits for games are fairly uncommon.

The game itself is great, though.

To bypass the craptastic 2K launcher which causes FPS and crashing issues:

1. Go to Library on your Steam client

2. Right click on Civilization VI, select properties

3. Select "Advanced Launch Options box"

4. Insert the following line:
[i]"C:\Program Files\Steam\SteamApps\common\Sid Meier's Civilization VI\Base\Binaries\Win64Steam\CivilizationVI.exe" %command%[/i]

[b]Please note that the given line is Steam folder by default, so if Steam is installed in a different drive (e.g. D: instead of C:), edit the line accordingly. Also, if you prefer playing the game with DirectX12, you may change CivilizationVI.exe to CivilizationVI_DX12.exe[/b]

Semi-Serious review:
I've played this game at least once a week for 2.5 years. If you like learning while you play and love anachronistic historical crossovers this is for you.

However, it must be said that the base game while not too bad, suffers from a bunch of strange design choices (static borders, no timers for friendships/alliances, annoyingly shallow strategic resource system, NO DIPLOMATIC VICTORY, etc), most if which were remedied in the expansions. its still worth your time, I had a blast the 1st year before Rise and Fall despite the annoyances. It also has had a few UI/gameplay changes added since then so the experience is likely smoother than mine 2 years ago.

All in all. If possible grab the full version will all expansions (75% off on the 2019 summer sale, YOU CAN'T LOSE) if you like to defy history and laugh while doing it.

2023 Edit: It's still a blast! I think at this point it's safe to say it has more than paid for itself in my case. One major problem now is that the DLLs have still not been released to my knowledge, which is not very good for the health of the modding scene for the game. Do it, make it live f o r e v e r.

I know this game gets a bit of a bad rap in some circles.  But it's honestly not bad.  Maybe not a total masterpiece, but I would still call it good.  The worst part is probably the AI being way too passive and having rather bizarre priorities.  And while I like that this game has been willing to experiment I'll admit that not every experiment panned out.  Still, there are reasons that Civilization is still the flagship franchise for historical 4x games.  The basic design is easy enough to grasp but hides a lot of potential complexity to keep people going for that one more turn after the last one more turn.  The game is also very good at providing a lot of visual information to the player at a glance which makes understanding the situation and forming a strategy a lot less tedious.  A lot of Civilization's competitors are really bad about that point.  In fact, poor documentation and unclear details such as terrain or resource presence seems to be a recurring problem in the strategy genre.  Civilization does not have that problem.  It is very good at giving you information and not hiding things.  The only really complaint I have in that department is that sometimes the presence and absence of hills is a little blurry.  But that's it really.

In terms of presentation, my thoughts are mixed.  The art style is perhaps a little too cartoony for my tastes.  It really does sometimes veer into the "mobile game" aesthetic.  That said, it's not as bad in that regard as some people make it out to be.  But one thing I can support fully:  the music.  Civilization has really been doing phenomenally in the music department these last few installments and I hope they keep that momentum going in VII.  The music isn't just very good, it is very varied.  Each Civilization has four versions of their central theme which is derived from actual historical music from that Civilization: Ancient, Medieval, Industrial, and Atomic.  Each version tries to mimic the broad style of those time periods.  Very basic tunes with limited instrumentation for the Ancient track, a still basic but with far more instrumental accompaniment that you might find in a generic medieval tavern in a larger city for the Medieval track, a symphonic arrangement that wouldn't have been out of place in the 1930's or 1940's for the Industrial track, and a Contemporary arrangement often featuring electronic instruments and digital sound effects while still maintaining a largely symphonic feel for the Atomic track; the sort of thing you might see in a lot of modern symphony performances and movie soundtracks.  And then each Civilization has additional Ambient tracks on top of that.  And all the Civilizations that appear in any given game have their themes and ambient music shuffled into your background music "play list" meaning that the sound never gets dull whether it's your first or five hundredth game.  Pretty much the only thing missing is a music select option for those who want it but honestly I could gush about the music all day.  The sound design is also on point though not quite  as good as the actual music though that is such a high bar to clear I can't blame it.  The point is playing this game can be quite enjoyable even beyond the gameplay and that is nothing to scoff at. 

TL;DR  It's a really good game despite a few occasional flaws.  It does a lot of things really well that a lot of people take for granted until they play another game and don't have those good points anymore.

I've played Civilization since Civ 1's release and will still continue to play an A.I. modded 'Civ 2 Test of Time' that vastly improves the A.I. in domination mode. I also love the option of building a spaceship and colonizing another planet on a second map that iteration of the game has and wish it was included in current editions of the game. I have yet to find a working A.I. mod that makes Civ 6 good in domination mode either.

Sid Meier's Civilization VI is an absolute masterpiece that flawlessly continues the legacy of one of the greatest strategy game franchises. As a long-time Civ fan, I can confidently say that this installment raises the bar even higher.

The first thing that strikes you is the breathtaking visual design. The art style is vibrant and engaging, making each turn feel like a step through a living, breathing world. The attention to detail in city animations, unit movements, and wonders is nothing short of awe-inspiring.

The gameplay is as addictive as ever, with the new district system adding an extra layer of depth to city planning. The strategic decisions you make carry real weight, impacting everything from culture and science to diplomacy and war. The introduction of unstacked cities gives a new dimension to urban planning, forcing you to consider the geographical layout of your empire carefully.

Diplomacy has also been revamped, and the addition of agendas for each leader adds a new level of unpredictability to interactions. Forming alliances and negotiating deals are more crucial than ever, and the diplomatic victory route is a welcome addition for those who prefer a peaceful path to world domination.

The variety of civilizations and leaders provide endless replayability. Each leader feels unique, not only in terms of abilities but also in the way they approach the game world. The inclusion of natural disasters adds a layer of unpredictability, making each playthrough feel like a fresh challenge.

Multiplayer is smoother than ever, with a robust online infrastructure that keeps games running seamlessly. The turn-based nature of the game makes it easy to manage, even with friends who might not be able to commit to long gaming sessions.

While the learning curve might be steep for newcomers, the in-game tutorial and Civilopedia do an excellent job of guiding you through the basics. Veterans, on the other hand, will appreciate the added complexity and strategic depth.

In conclusion, Civilization VI is a triumph in both design and execution. It captures the essence of what makes the series great while introducing enough new elements to keep things exciting. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, this game is a must-play for anyone who enjoys the thrill of building and leading a civilization through the ages.

To bypass 2K dumb and greedy launcher which causes crashing or fps problem:
Library -> Right click on Civilization VI -> Properties -> Advanced Launch Options box -> Insert this line

"C:\Program Files\Steam\SteamApps\common\Sid Meier's Civilization VI\Base\Binaries\Win64Steam\CivilizationVI.exe" %command%

(Note: the line is Steam folder by default, if you change your Steam folder location, customize the line to your Steam folder location; if you want to play the game with DX12, change CivilizationVI.exe to CivilizationVI_DX12.exe)

I'll probably keep playing for untold hours because it's a Civ game and my body needs that sort of thing.

- "From the first stirrings of life beneath water... to the great beasts of the Stone Age... to man taking his first upright steps, you have come far."  If you read that and just thought, "wait, didn't bipedalism predate the Stone Age?  And why 'Stone Age' when the term is defined by man's tool making when other prior ages also had megafauna without screwing up the sequence?," you have considered the writing more than the designers did generally.
- Folks, should the in-game Civilopedia tell you what technology is needed to unlock particular buildings and infrastructure, and if not, what would be the harm in doing so?  I don't work at EA so this is impossible for me to answer.
- Speaking of oversights, just about every unit that you select to go off to a far location will do so inefficiently, ignoring an excess of water movement in favor of crawling up on land and wasting points to get to the same location.  You'd think they'd fix this at some point with all the packs and expansions, but nay.  It's also possible, if not likely, that you'll have issues with the "City Focus" tools to there the on-board all-production focus ends up generating less than the default setting.
- Micromanagement creep is worse than ever with district bonuses and wonder placements.  The sad thing is that even though Districts have their inherent bonuses, they don't [i]feel[/i] as good to place as actual buildings and so it just drags out the process with extra steps.  As for Wonders, some of the demands are rather ridiculous, like "you can't build this unless you have a Commercial District with a Bank next to a cattle pasture."  There are perhaps dozens like this which I never see or build because I don't have the meta to do so.  Districts and Wonders, once begun are also locked into position, so it's not like you can undo it later.  A final dumb aspect of District and Wonder placement is that if you place them on a Forest or Rainforest tile, you don't get the production bonus from the trees, they just vanish, so if you wanted that, you would have had to have sent a Builder in to clear the tile first. 
- Even without the bonuses from their beliefs, enemies will aggressively spread religion at you and you can't actually get them to stop even when asking.
- Every World Congress, you vote more or less blind to what the other Civs intend to do and they will mostly gang up on you to screw over your resources and amenities.
- Being able to pair a unit with a Great Person is neat, but as the unit rotation goes around, they'll always go first, rather than the combat unit receiving their bonuses and which can actually attack.  Why?
- Extra large culture output cities will start raiding nearby cities for their edge tiles even though they can't work them using citizens and in many cases provide no bonuses.  Again, WHY?
- For reasons not particularly well articulated, you can't move Great Works around easily and are mostly locked into their positions unless you happen to have equivalent slots to swap with.  This sounds and is unnecessarily complicated, especially when certain buildings have wildcard slots that can accept a variety of works, but refuse to recognize their own ability to swap out elsewhere.  Once more: WHY?
- No automatic terrain benefits to using scouts.  You have to promote them to get any.
- Crossing a river is the most difficult task you can ask a unit to do.  It will take years off their life.
- "Ages" don't always make sense and you may be coasting along only to find that your opponent did something big and you now have <10 turns to pull yourself out of a potential Dark Age.  Some of them can also rocket on by you because you're progressing too fast except if you didn't get the requisite bonuses, you're also going straight off a cliff into a Dark Age.
- "Climate" seems like something the devs just threw together as an afterthought.  It doesn't make a whole lot of sense and mostly brings in the random events few appreciated in Civ IV, except now their immediate consequences are always negative and may only have some positives later.  Buy some volcano insurance, yeah?  GS will start you next to one 5-10% of the time.
- Find espionage obnoxious?  Well, you can't disable it anymore.
- The Big One (for me at least): The quotes that accompany building wonders or discovering civic / techs suck.  Many are now either Nerd Shit or "how clever am I, a modern human, for dragging the peoples of the past?" or random underwhelming quotes from the internet or quotes from people I just don't want to hear from (Reagan, Thatcher, Ailes, Rand... all leaning hard to the right).   I don't need a grandiose quote for everything (the Thoreau quote for the Great Lighthouse sucks, BTW, but no one in America is willing to admit that they only think Thoreau is good because he talks about nature and uses words they've never seen), but having the narrative voice diss you for completing objectives that have been in several iterations of the game is off-putting.

The good?

+ Features like forests don't get removed with lumbermills.  That's fun.
+ Lenses are good, if buggy a lot of the time in getting a read on Religion. 
+ Late-game additions help alleviate past gameplay lulls in the modern eras.
+ Each Civ has a musical theme that evolves with their technological progress.
+ Builders with finite uses are preferable to mobs of Workers dragging out turns and memory.
+ Governors have some interesting bonuses and can supercharge some aspect of a city's theming.
+ More unique city-state bonuses like specific tile improvements.  They're not all just a category anymore.
+ GUI is somewhat better now, although mods improve it significantly (Hills are VERY difficult to detect without a mod).
+ Corps, armada, et al were a good way of correcting Civ V's issues without the horrifying stacks of ten units you got in Civ IV.
+ Decoupling Wonders from the city center was probably a good idea ultimately and you can appreciate them better as individual tiles.
+ More resources, more wonders, more civs.  I'm not one of those weirdo western supremacy dorks who shits a brick every time he sees a brown or lady leader or God Forbid both.  I think it's neat.

This was my first Civ game.  I just started playing other 4x-type games (simple ones, like Sorcerer King and Thea 1) back then, and was totally new to Civ.  I thought I may not like it, as I was much, MUCH more attracted to fantasy world 4x titles, but I actually really did like it.  I didn't LOVE It, but I can see how millions of others do love the ???? out of it.  

As for the artstyle compared to past Civ games, I'm all for it.  I like the way Civ 5 looks and I also like the way 6 looks.  Probably moreso, as I already stated I'm more into fantasy (and therefore, stylized graphics).

Anyway, this game has been PHENOMENALLY cheap for the last several years.  I'm actually shocked at the discounts they give for a flagship game like this.  Blows my mind.  That said, and taking into account just how GOOD this game is at what it does (no one does it better, yet), this is a solid 100% recommendation from me.  

And, no, you don't need the expansions.  If you don't own the game yet you most likely aren't a Civ fanatic, so playing the vanilla game may even be better for you.  I still am.  But if you want them the DLC can be found fairly cheaply as well.

TIP FROM ME:    Those of you with a decent (980 from nvidia or maybe AMD Fury from 2014/15) gpu and a big-screen tv -- try finding a steam controller online (new or used - should still be cheap, even though they are discontinued and disappearing).  Playing 4X games from my couch/bed at 4K on a 55" TV with my Steam Controller has completely changed the way I game.  ANY game with keyboard/mouse controls that isn't hyper fast (like counterstrike or LoL) plays exceptionally well with a steam controller + big screen TV.  Game changer (literally ;)

Although there are few things that are still lacking, like AI improvement and a centralized workshop for both Epic and Steam. This Civilization 6 deserves to be appreciated for its effort not just simply a copy paste gameplay from its predecessor. But rather, as a good example of how the developer try to introduce new gameplay as well polishing their franchise system holistically. 

P/S: Having Sean Bean as the narrator during my conquest made me unstoppable. One does not simply quit the game before nuking the AI.

I was recommended to play civilization series since 1990s when my bestie indulged himself in Civ 3. I did not dare to dab into the series because I knew these kind of games is addictive and time consuming.
I changed my mind and became a fan in Civ 5, tbh this is still my best pick in the series, because the reduction in complexity and acceleration of game pace made the entry more accessible.
Civ 6 did a few good improvements, namely the upgraded religion system made a difference (I think in civ 5 religion was not that important). but the district system is not my cup of tea.
The other thing I don't like is the piece meal DLC that hide leaders that I like by another paywall, but this is the standard industry practices nowadays, I cannot complain too much. 
Overall, this is a solid entry, if you are a newcomer, skip the plethora of cosmetic DLCs, only go for the two major expansions, if you a rich, just grab the complete edition, try it, then try civ 5.

I've enjoyed playing this title for many years now. It's fun, but the next real big step in my eyes is adjusting the AI difficulty. It's sad at best, and the only real thing that increasing the difficulty does is handicap the other opponents so that they produce more and start with more land. I want a more comprehensive AI that decides on win strategies that it can adjust as the game progresses. The AI's ability to wage war is effectively null, as they cower from attacking at almost all costs unless they possess overwhelming odds, which they will expend haphazardly until they're all but destroyed. Then they always sue for peace as soon as something goes bad. . .  Other than that the game is visually appealing, i like the way the turn based system works, even in tandem with other players while they're not at war!

Title: "Epic Journey Through Time: Sid Meierâ€™s Civilization VI"

Rating: â­â­â­â­â­ (5/5)

If you're a fan of strategy games that transcend the boundaries of time and space, look no further than Sid Meier's Civilization VI. This game is a masterpiece that effortlessly combines the thrill of exploration, the intricacies of diplomacy, and the pulse-pounding excitement of warfare, all set against the backdrop of human history.

One of the standout features of Civilization VI is its breathtaking attention to detail in recreating the rise and fall of civilizations. The game's stunning visuals and intricately designed maps make each playthrough a visually immersive experience. From the bustling cities to the serene landscapes, every element is meticulously crafted, making it a true feast for the eyes.

The depth of gameplay is unparalleled. The strategic decisions you make, from selecting your civilization's leader to managing resources and navigating diplomatic relationships, have a profound impact on the course of the game. The addition of districts and wonders adds an extra layer of complexity, allowing for a more nuanced and strategic approach to city planning.

Diplomacy in Civilization VI is a dynamic and engaging experience. Negotiating with other leaders, forming alliances, and making critical decisions on the global stage are all integral to success. The inclusion of agendas for each leader adds a layer of unpredictability, ensuring that each game feels fresh and full of surprises.

One of the most satisfying aspects of the game is the way it captures the essence of human progress. As you guide your civilization through the ages, from the ancient era to the modern age and beyond, you'll witness the evolution of society, technology, and culture. The sense of accomplishment as you advance through the eras and achieve milestones is truly gratifying.

The multiplayer experience is seamless, allowing you to compete or cooperate with friends in epic battles for supremacy. The well-designed online infrastructure ensures a smooth and enjoyable multiplayer experience, adding replayability to an already content-rich game.

In conclusion, Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a triumph in the world of strategy gaming. Its captivating blend of history, strategy, and diplomacy creates an experience that is not only intellectually stimulating but also incredibly fun. Whether you're a seasoned Civilization veteran or a newcomer to the series, this game is a must-play. Sid Meier's Civilization VI sets a new standard for the genre, offering a rich and rewarding gaming experience that will keep you coming back for more.

"When 'One More Turn' Becomes 'One More Century'!"

Civilization VI is the game that turns every intention of going to bed at 10 p.m. into an epic saga that ends with the sunrise. Every time you say "Just one more turn," you end up building the Pyramids, getting embroiled in a cultural revolution, or conquering one more city.

It's like trying to quit chocolate, but you know that eventually, you'll succumb to temptation and build a "Chocolate Factory." It's just a matter of time.

In Civilization VI, you get to be the leader of the world, but you also get to make colossal strategic blunders, like losing your entire army because you tried to cross a river in the dead of winter. It's like asking George Washington to trudge through the snow with his wooden teeth â€“ it won't work, but at least you'll have a hilarious story. :)

The game's graphics are stunning, and the leader animations are so expressive that you feel like you're truly negotiating with Teddy Roosevelt or having a WhatsApp argument with Cleopatra. Maybe she can't build pyramids, but she can certainly construct drama!

In conclusion, Civilization VI is a game that will make you feel like a real-world leader â€“ a leader who can choose to build their empire or bring it to a spectacular downfall. So, if you want to experience what it's like to lead a civilization until the early hours and wonder where the time went, Civilization VI is the game for you. But beware, because "One More Turn" eventually turns into "One More Century," and you can't escape!

[b] Pros [/b]
 - An engaging 4X game with enough depth to satisfy seasoned strategists, but enough simplicity to not be *too* overwhelming for new players.
- A larger focus on city planning than Civilization V - an additional level of strategy the game greatly benefits from.
- A massive level of customisation, keeping the game fresh after you've played hundreds of games already.
- Continued support from devs 7 years after initial release
[b] Cons [/b]
- This game is unstable as hell at times. Sometimes (i.e. all the time) the game will lock up without crashing; depending on your setup this could be a quick close and reopen, but if you're on a low-end machine (like me) more often than not it means a full system restart.
- 2K launcher icky (just go back to the old launcher please I beg)
- Non-sale price tag for the game + DLC is ridiculous

[b] Conclusion [/b]
Overall, some of the most fun strategy gameplay the series has to offer, but it's constantly bogged down by the game being buggy as hell. Pick this one up on sale. [b] 7.5/10 [/b]

English:

Homemade LandjÃ¤ger Sausage

Ingredients:
- 500 g beef
- 500 g pork
- 20 g curing salt (nitrite curing salt)
- 5 g coarse ground pepper
- 5 g sweet paprika
- 3 g garlic powder
- 2 g ginger powder
- 2 g dried marjoram
- 1 g ground coriander
- 1 g grated nutmeg
- 1 g ground cardamom
- Pork casings for stuffing
- Kitchen twine

Instructions:
1. Cut the beef and pork into small pieces and pass them through a meat grinder with a coarse plate.
2. Place the ground meat in a large bowl and add all the spices (curing salt, pepper, paprika, garlic powder, ginger powder, marjoram, coriander, nutmeg, and cardamom). Mix well until the spices are evenly distributed.
3. Cover the meat mixture and let it rest in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours to allow the flavors to develop.
4. Thoroughly clean the pork casings and soak them in cold water to soften.
5. Remove the meat mixture from the refrigerator and knead it again to ensure proper blending.
6. Stuff the meat mixture into the prepared pork casings, ensuring there are no air pockets and that the casings are evenly filled.
7. Cut the filled casings into approximately 10 cm long pieces and tie the ends with kitchen twine.
8. Hang the LandjÃ¤ger sausages in a cool place to dry for about 2-3 weeks. The ideal temperature is around 15-18 degrees Celsius.
9. After the drying period, the LandjÃ¤ger sausages are ready to be consumed. They can be enjoyed raw or lightly pan-fried.

Note: When making sausage, it is important to maintain proper hygiene. Ensure all utensils are thoroughly cleaned, and use fresh meat. It is also recommended to familiarize yourself with basic sausage-making principles and consider employing specific sausage-making techniques.

I didn't care for this as much as Civ IV or V in the beginning because I was salty about city districts, stupid AI diplomacy, and diminished wonder bonuses. Although I am still salty about these things, I've found that it is actually fun to explore different gameplay styles. I was in a bit of a Civ rut, only playing with the same leaders and strategies, and this is different enough to bring some fresh air into the franchise. The districts feature forces you to be a lot more intentional about your strategy from the beginning instead of just going with the flow and kind of picking out your victory as you go. That is a little more challenging, but also kind of fun. Still, though, you declare one war in 2000 BC, and civilizations that never even met the poor saps you declared war on will denounce you as a warmonger over and over until the end of time. It will be 1950 and China will still be mad at you for declaring war on Rome back when they were still researching the wheel. And wonders are not even really worth building. They cost hella production, AND a land tile, and you get something lame like +5 culture. Ultimately, I'm into it and I will probably keep on playing.

Let me first say I have spent a good chunk of time on this game, and it's certainly addicting. I've bought all the DLC (my wallet!) and truly loved the game for almost 2,000 hours now.

Strategy is a main part of the game, but I'm dumb, so I always play on normal difficulty (Prince) and I usually just abuse really good civilizations to win.

It has nice graphics. Nothing to write home about, but it's a nice background to the gameplay.

Mods keep the game afloat. After 7 years the game has gotten a bit stale, and mods help keep it fresh.

Also, apparently they removed the menu screen in the newest update?
Uh... okay then.

But seriously, as younger me said, "It's an awesome turn-based game, and I loved it! 10/10."

Introduction

A strategy game on a grand scale.

It combines expansion, economy, discovery and combat.
A classic in its latest version.

Gameplay : 4/5
Graphics : 4/5
Music : 5/5
Sound Effects : 5/5
Voice Over Narrations : 5/5
Storyline: 3/5

Overal Note : 4/5

Positive :

A beautifully developed engine that I still associate with Beyond Earth. Beautifully crafted UI.

Absolutely beautiful music.

Development of the engine in a direction unknown from previous editions.

Multiple gameplay configuration options.

Unique AI personalities.

Negative :

Unfortunately, after three days of play, the game crashed and froze. This is not a big problem, because if we have autosave turned on, we do not lose much. But one.

The further civilizations develop, the longer it takes to wait for opponents to move..

Barbarians appear periodically and quite often in heavily settled areas of the tundra. (it is possible to play without barbarians, but it also takes away the flavor of the game)

There are no epic quotes from throughout the history and Morgan Freeman quotes like Civ 4 was.
The new narrator has a nice voice, but it's not the same.

A very aggressive publisher's policy towards add-ons. For example, 2 other civilizations cost $10 and some require $50-60 in a package.

Moving away from ancient quotes in favor of modern ones and political correctness. 

Overal Review :

A very nice installment of the series. It has many advantages and a few shortcomings compared to previous editions.

The game level has become more relaxing and easier, you don't feel so much pressure from the opponents even on the Prince and King levels.

The multitude of possibilities for victory is an additional advantage.

The downside is the publisher's aggressive policy towards add-ons.

Devs couldn't figure out how to program an AI that could outplay a human so the AI cheats at higher difficulties with better yields, combat stats and starting units. Anything lower than King difficulty is a braindead easy compstomp, anything higher than Emperor is you getting obliterated by a balls-out-cheating AI that is 3 cities ahead of you by turn 25. Then there's a cute little animation of them telling you how much you suck. Counterplay in higher difficulties means cheesing broken AI more than employing any kind of real strategy. Survive until you can nuke cities, because the AI doesn't use nukes, for whatever reason. Late-game is also very static and uninteresting.

I love Civ 6. I have every DLC. I have over 2k hours on it between Steam and Epic launcher. I have recommended it to all of my friends that will listen (and to a lot that won't). They've also started doing timed events where you can pit yourself against players around the world in a scripted scenario for the highest score, so even several years after launch, it's still getting new content.

So why in the name of God am I leaving a negative review?

Because they've started putting ads on the homescreen. 

Now, the ad on the homescreen at the moment is for Julius Caesar, the free DLC leader added a little while ago. On the whole, Caesar is fun. But shoving ads in our faces like this sets a BAD precedent in a game that was ad-free before (not counting the tiny bar at the bottom of the home screen, which was honestly barely noticeable).

The sixth installment in a series that's been around since the dawn of time, or at least since the dawn of computer games. But hey, who's counting? If you've played any of the previous Civilization games, you'll feel right at home here. It's like they took the best bits from the previous games, added a few new features, and then sprinkled some magic dust on top. The result? A game that's as addictive as ever. You'll find yourself saying, "Just one more turn," until you realize it's 3 AM and you've got work in a few hours. But who needs sleep when you're on a quest for world domination, right? The game's got a learning curve, sure, but once you get the hang of it, you'll be hooked. And if you're new to the series, well, welcome to the club. We've got cookies. And empires to build.

i came back to this game after about 4 years off.  and it's still broken and pointless after about 5 different game tries.  

i played on emperor difficulty and this is what i found.  the ai spawns setlers very aggressively and builds in the tiny areas between your cities that you thought would be pointless area to build another city.  even if that makes their empire non continuous.  at this point they are just trolling you.  

then some games the barbarians are so overwhelming that you are handicapped from the start for about 20 to 30 turns before you can do anything else besides building warriors.  and by then from what i found out is that you will be so far behind in everything that you may as well start a new game.  i had 5 horsemen surround my town and destroy the 3 city improvements i made.  and i was stuck in that state for a very long time.  i ended the play through after i defeated them and then just got to the industrial era and found that while i had mamluks (knights) the french where attacking me with infantry.  one shot kills.  i assume its because of the 30 turns i spent doing nothing but trying to get rid of 5 horsemen barbarians around my capital.  i couldn't even expand.  

all in all the ai is silly and makes the game super dumb.  after 6 years they still cant get a hold of the ai.  its really bad. 

the game forces you to rush barbarians and go for an all out domination victory.  if you try and do anything else there is no point.  the ai will beat you to it because of the huge bonuses they give them.  instead of focusing on giving the ai some semblance of strategy and intelligence.  they make it dumb but with a near unlimited pool of wealth to pull from at the start making them OP.    case and point is that when you are evenly matched against the AI in terms of starting resources and units (the ai gets none), the game becomes a cake walk and not worth playing.  like beating up on children.

Game is buggy after so many years of development. 

Additional content thru DLCs are typically not worth the price of admission and introduction of new mechanics and features tend to be halfarsed at best. 

Ai is not competent at all and will have issues fielding combat units mid to late game due to not being developed to plan ahead and to preserve units created earlier in a play thru. They had the means to as features such as preferred city locations is present and noted ingame. However, the Ai has difficulty working around the basic mechanics created in this new iteration of Civilization. 

Ex: Combat should be similar to other turn based tile set strategy games. But, the Ai was programmed to just move about with little to no guidance. Units that need time to setup will move about every turn invalidating what they can do. Others that should be offensive will idle or leave strategic locations stranding civilians, infrastructure and aforementioned ranged units to be wiped out. 

Ai will over create unused infrastructure and consume resource deposits for small early game boosts that will leave it unable to compete late game with the player. And is entirely reliant on artificial boosts to attempt to compete. Tho there are enough win conditions to keep the Ai in a playthru, as the player a win is simply just focusing on any one of those conditions. 

The Ai was never given the means to compete and I'm pretty sure it's due to Firaxis stringing spaghetti code along from game to game instead of fixing the mess. MP boils down to who picked the right Civ and got the better starting location. 

And the game spams so much that I'm not entirely sure they know what spam is.

For context, the only other Civ game I played was Civ 4 like, one game, and I love deep strategy games. I've now played this game twice through in three days (two diplomatic victories!). If you choose to play, say goodbye to healthy sleeping or eating habits. Say goodbye to your friends and family. Say goodbye to your job. Just make sure you have enough pizza and Mountain Dew because this game will not let you go until you win or literally die.

The one major con with this game is, despite there being a "civopedia", almost nothing is explained, and things that are explained are explained atrociously. You are basically required to look everything up online because the game does such a poor job explaining things.

A minor con that I found very annoying is, after you build a wonder, because they usually take a while to build and you forget what they did, you can't click or hover it on the game map to see what effects it gives. It would be great if you could do that to see what benefits you're getting, but you have to either go back through your tech or civic tree to see where you unlocked it and hover there or look it up in your civopedia. It's not horrible since the info is still accessible, it's just bad UX.

Anyways, highly recommend. Great game. I'm going to sleep for the first time in 3 days.

[h1]This sums up how I feel when playing Civilization games from a pacifistic standpoint[/h1]

"I'm sorry, but I don't want to be an emperor. That's not my business. I don't want to rule or conquer anyone. I should like to help everyone if possible - Jew, Gentile, Black man, White. We all want to help one another. Human beings are like that. We want to live by each other's happiness not by each other's misery. We don't want to hate and despise one another. In this world, there's room for everyone, and a good earth is rich and can provide for everyone.

The way of life can be free and beautiful, but we have lost the way. Greed has poisoned men's souls, has barricaded the world with hate, has goose-stepped us into misery and bloodshed. We have developed speed, but we have shut ourselves in. Machinery that gives abundance has left us in want. Our knowledge has made us cynical. Our cleverness, hard and unkind. We think too much and feel too little. More than machinery, we need humanity. More than cleverness, we need kindness and gentleness. Without these qualities, life will be violent, and all will be lost.

The aeroplane and the radio have brought us closer together. The very nature of these inventions cries out for the goodness in men; cries out for universal brotherhood, for the unity of us all. Even now, my voice is reaching millions throughout the world; millions of despairing men, women, and children; victims of a system that makes men torture and imprison innocent people.

For those who can hear me, I say - do not despair. The misery that is now upon us is but the passing of greed, the bitterness of men who fear the way of human progress, the hate of men will pass, and dictators die. The power they took from the people will return to the people, and so long as men die, liberty will never perish.

Soldiers, don't give yourselves to brutes - men who despise you, enslave you, who regiment your lives; tell you what to do, what to think, or what to feel; who drill you, diet you, treat you like cattle, use you as cannon fodder! Don't give yourselves to these unnatural men - machine men with machine minds and machine hearts! You are not machines! You are not cattle! You are men! You have the love of humanity in your hearts. You don't hate. Only the unloved hate - the unloved and the unnatural.

Soldiers, don't fight for slavery! Fight for liberty! In the 17th chapter St. Luke it is written the kingdom of God is within man. Not one man, nor a group of men, but in all men! In you! You, the people, have the power - the power to create machines, the power to create happiness! You, the people, have the power to make this life free and beautiful; to make this life a wonderful adventure.

Then in the name of democracy, let us use that power! Let us all unite! Let us fight for a new world, a decent world that will give men a chance to work; that will give youth a future and old age a security. By the promise of these things, brutes have risen to power, but they lie. They do not fulfill that promise. They never will! Dictators free themselves, but they enslave the people!

Now let us fight to fulfill that promise. Let us fight to free the world, to do away with national barriers, to do away with greed, with hate, and intolerance. Let us fight for a world of a reason, a world where science and progress will lead to all men's happiness. 

Soldiers, in the name of democracy, let us all unite!" -Charlie Chaplin

You know, as much as I liked recent turned-based 4X games like Humankind and Old World, going back to Civilization 6 has me convinced that it still rules the pack.  There's just something almost magical about the way the game encompasses all of human history, bringing together culture, economics, politics, science, espionage, and yes, war, in one glorious whole, and does so in a sometimes lighthearted fashion.  With the cartoonish caricatures of the civ leaders, to say nothing of the sometimes hilarious technology and civics quotes (beautifully read by the great actor Sean Bean), it seems clear that the Firaxis devs don't take themselves too, too seriously, and that's a good thing.  

One thing new the game brings to the table I like very much is the government policy cards which allows a lot of subtlety and nuance in the way you govern your civilization.  The city districts and adjacency bonuses is also an interesting addition, and sometimes necessitates careful growth planing of your cities.  The World Congress is mostly good, simulating as it does the Council of Nicea, League of Nations, UN, etc, though I did find a mod that improves on this experience.   

Visually the game is very attractive to the eye, with beautiful natural and man-made wonders, great environmental effects like hurricanes and volcanic eruptions, and an overall very pleasing art style.  While I'm on the subject of visuals, a special mention needs to be made of the rocket launches.  They are as beautiful as they are epic, the gfx artists absolutely knocked the ball out of the park here!

Not to criticize Humankind (a game which I mostly enjoy) too much, but one thing I think Civ6 does much better is almost everything related to the modern age.  I mean, in Humankind I found the modern age rather boring at a time when the game should be at its most exciting. Further, the space race in Humankind was laughably easy and a huge disappointment, visually as well as gameplay wise.  In Civ6, however, you can feel the tension of the heightened pace in the modern age with lots of things going on, and the space race is a moderately complex and stressful affair that rewards you greatly when you get it right.  

A word about the music.  Awesome!  Best music I've ever heard in a strategy game.  Much of it will be recognizable to many people, like Lovely Joan for England, Waltzing Matilda for Australia, Hard Times Come Again No More for the United States, Recuerdos de la Alhambra for Spain, many others.  Further, I love how the musicians take a theme like the English folk song Scarborough Fair and make the arrangements increasingly progressive as you advance through the ages, to the point where by the post-modern era it's full on techno! 

Concerning the AI, I know a lot of players complain about it being dumb, but I don't know.  In my experience I sometimes see the AI doing some ill-advised things, but other times I've been surprised by some very clever moves.  Bottom line for me is the game's AI has never been bad enough to ruin the experience or take me out of the moment.  Maybe my biggest complaint is the same as it's always been in the Civ series.  That is, it will sometimes take me 10-15 restarts before I get a starting position that I'm happy with.  As every Civ player knows, your starting position is super important.  Also, I hate the Giant Death Robot.  To my mind it seriously hurts endgame, as in a stroke it makes your entire very expensive late game military obsolete.  Thank heavens I found a mod that turns them off.  

Anyway, I love this game.  I know this because of the very warm and satisfied feeling I had from completing my latest one, compelling me to write this glowing review.  It is as fun as it is educational, and as far as I'm concerned Firaxis can take their time with Civilization 7, as I'm far from finished with 6.  

Thanks for taking the time to read this.  :)

[i]"Although it pains me to do this, I have to give Civilization 6 a thumbs down.
It's just not fun. After a few games of this I just went back to playing V."[/i] [h3]- I wrote that 6 years, probably dozens of patches ago, and I've even played Civ IV. Now (2023) I've decided to give Civ 6 another shot. Let's see if my criticisms still hold up or did it redeem itself? [/h3]
[h3]Old review text in Italics.[/h3]

[h2]2023 Update[/h2]

[i]I'll try to list everything I find positive about the game over V: [/i] [list]
[*][i]"Instead of passively impressing every city state just for existing, you now have a new system that encourages you to influence your favorites."[/i] [h3]- This still holds up. It allows for more varied strategies and "soft power" you can't directly production your way out of. [/h3]
[*][i]Religion now matters, as a Victory. [/i][h3] - Although it was a neat buff in V, Enemy Religion wasn't a giant threat. It sure is now. There's even a religious combat system. [/h3]
[*][i]Vastly different Civilization abilities [b]almost[/b] make each game feel unique.[/i] [h3] -  Mostly remove the "almost" there. Many Civs now come packaged with zany abilities.[/h3]
[*][i]Much easier moddability.[/i] [h3] - By this I mean mod use. Civ V required you to manually load each mod every time you wanted to play it, and it broke my Vox Populi game between when I wrote this review originally and now. I still do not forgive it. [/h3]
[*][i]Sean "I am Fond of Pigs" Bean's narration is fantastic, it is one of the few things that never gets old about this game.[/i] [h3] - Still great, no arguments there. [/h3]
[/list]
[i]Now the, unfortunately, longer list of Cons. Especially downgrades from V: [/i] [list]
[*][i]Everything feels restrictive, especially the Eureka/Inspiration System.
  The Eureka/Inspiration was designed to give players a boost depending on what they do, but it has the exact opposite effect instead.
  Every time you play, you'll want the boosts. You'll build exactly three Crossbow Men, you'll always found at least one coastal city, and you'll always go around trying to maximize your boosts.[/i] [h3] - This is still mostly valid, but Rise and Fall [b]did[/b] reduce the Boosts to 40% instead of 50% which I feel is a lot more fair. I've gotten used to it, it even gives a trade-off of whether you think an unboosted technology is worth it. It does, however, allow you to dunk on the AI. [/h3]
  [i]Contrast this with Civ 5, where I'd usually find myself in a sticky situation when I focused too much on buildings, and there could be Civs without access to water. Every game was actually unique, and strategies might have to adapt.[/i] [h3] - Focusing too much on buildings in Civ V? Impossible.
In all seriousness, this is really a trade of production for a certain amount of Science/Culture when it comes to Boosts. I would've liked semi-randomized Boosts so that you're not overly rewarded for simply remembering them all, but oh well. [/h3]
[*][i]Diplomacy is an absolute joke. Several AI Civs will hate you for performing well, and the others will hate you after you annex an entire country "In Self Defense" when another AI attacks you for no reason.[/i] [h3] - [b]Absolutely not applicable with Gathering Storm with the addition of the Grievances system. Rise and Fall also removed the "Close to Winning" negative opinion modifier. Vanilla will still suffer though.[/b] In my experience, the AI is a lot less "stupidly aggressive" than before on the middling difficulties. [/h3]
[*][i]There is only one way to win, more cities. In V you could dominate the game with only a few cities, in 6 you have to blob (and the AI is terrible at it).[/i] [h3]- [b]Gee past-me, and how was "Anything but tall" in V like? Was it terrible? I remember it being terrible due to the Science cost penalties.[/b] It's almost like competing for land and resources that breed conflicts should actually drive the game forward instead of hitting "End Turn" 400 times in my handful of hypercities.[/h3]
[*][i]The AI is an absolute joke. The only threat they pose is that they'll break every single promise the turn after they make it.[/i] [h3]- My first game back was with the Cree where I made a giant "hugbox" against Arabia, it was hilarious. The new grievances system in Gathering Storm fixes the other part where now you can beat the stuffing out of a lying AI and everyone will clap for you.[/h3]
[*][i]Decentralizing cities is supposed to make it look like urban sprawl and give a tactical choice to city development, but I'm a real "Make Every City Amazing" kinda guy and it really bothers me. It doesn't feel like your city is progressing.[/i] [h3]- I've mostly 180'd on this as districts allow for tactical choices and adjacency bonuses, though I would've enjoyed cities' models being a bit "sprawl-ier."[/h3]
[*][i]Speaking of progress, that's another thing Civ 6 lacks. Eras don't really feel like they're progressing, just going through the motions. Your territory doesn't feel like a vast expanse, but a disjointed mass of cities. It feels like you're just playing a game, not building a Civilization.[/i] [h3]- The new "Ages" system does partially fix this in my eyes but it does tie into a deeper issue of the game's "arcade-y" original design.[/h3]
[/list]
[i]A real shame, I was very excited about Civ 6. I kept looking online every day to see which Civ would be included, wondering who would show up next. Over the past year I've played a few games, but kept feeling something was missing. 
Civilization 6 is just not fun, and that's tragic. Hopefully a future patch can change this sad game into something great.[/i] [h3]- "Hopefully a future patch can change this sad game into something great." Well, did it happen? [b]Yes[/b]. Civ VI fixed most of their problems, and mods fix quite a bit more of them. 
What turned me off originally was that the game felt very "arcade-y" from its artstyle to its gameplay. Civ V's art-deco style made it feel dignified, that I am truly building a civilization. I think Civ VI can capture that, at least a little bit, now. 
Civ VI is still a bit silly, but it's finally worthy of a thumbs up.[/h3]

*Update* I love civilization games and I keep getting the urge to play this...but then I stumbled on all the reviews about red shell and how this game literally installs 3rd party spyware on your computer. Great way to kill off Civilization 2k Games I hope you milked it enough.

Update 2. They have removed Red Shell which was their tracking spyware. Awesome. I saw the game on sale some of my friends were getting it so I reinstalled to play with them. I was dissapointed. How on earth is a supposed "AAA" game from a well funded studio unable to fix its AI 1 year after launch? It's frankly embarrassing and sadly probably the last civilization game I'm getting. Paradox Interactive might pump out a lot of DLC for its games but at least the games are well supported, patched, and updated with new content. I'll take Paradox' pseudo subscription regular dlc over this broken mess.

Update 3. Congratulations Civilization 6. It took you $100 worth of DLC and 2.5 years in development to finally be better than Civilization 5! It's even more embarrassing when you realize that a lot of that new "content" was just re-adding things that Civ 5 had. The game is better than Civ5 now. It's actually fun to play and a great game.

That said I refuse to change this to a positive recommendation. Get it on sale. Civilization games should not take 3 years worth of dlc and patching to become better than the last Civilization game.

Hey there, strugglers! It's me, Guts, the guy Griffith couldn't keep his dreams away from. Now, I know what you're thinking â€“ what's a guy who's been through the Eclipse doing reviewing Civilization VI? Well, we all need a break from demon-slaying and Brand-marked vendettas, right?

In this game, you're not out there swinging a massive sword and battling apostles, but you get to build cities, research tech, and form alliances. It's like running a Band of the Hawk, but without the betrayal â€“ we hope. Speaking of betrayal, remember Griffith? Well, he couldn't even lead a civ to save his life, so you'll do just fine.

Now, the AI here can be as predictable as Griffith's ambition, making deals and breaking 'em faster than he did our friendship. But, hey, that's part of the fun, right?

The graphics won't make you ascend to godhood like Griffith did (if you consider that a good thing), but they're decent. The soundtrack won't make you question the nature of reality like the God Hand, but it's catchy enough.

In the end, Civilization VI may not have you wielding the Dragon Slayer, but it's a nice way to spend some time away from Griffith's treacherous schemes. So go ahead and conquer the world, just like I did with my inner demons. Give it a try, and remember â€“ even Griffith can't ruin this game for you!

Tips for new players: Always become friends with the Darwinists. You can warmonger without penalty to them. 

Science is important, as it allows you to get new technologies faster. 

If you plan to be religious, consider being a theocracy. This allows you to buy troops with faith. 

Science victory is the easiest victory. If you see someone launch the moon landing it may be a good idea to nuke them (to prevent further progress)

Nukes are a strong diplomatic tool, don't use them too often though as they can cause your people to revolt if you don't have enough amenities. This is because they cause heavy war weariness.

To use Nukes as a diplomatic tool, wage war on someone. Then nuke them a couple times, and demand a couple cities as well as whatever you wanted. They'll often accept, if they don't accept nuke them further.

Civ 6 overall is great but dated now, with respect to the graphics and mechanics. But this review is specifically for the Apocalypse mode. 

The Apocalypse game mode is horrible, over-tuned to an absurd degree. Within a 20 turn period 6 of my cities were lost to comets, and two ally city states, after which I had no win conditions. This was not symmetrical to the AI.  Even in a ramped up end of days scenario, it's too much. To come from behind after one or two cities are hit, sure. but this much is pure frustration, zero fun. 

The comets are bad, but could be tuned. The solar flares are worse, and irredeemably bad. Certainly one of the dumbest, most boring mechanics I've ever seen in a game. Every time a solar flare comes, I have to repair every most of my key districts in my entire civilization (campus and industry). By the time that is done, 5 turns later another flare. What play patterns are the devs going for, here? Lots and lots of clicking and waiting to achieve nothing? It's just time sucking busy work to click repair over and over and over. You can't even queue a repair of a building until the district is repaired, multiplying the number of clicks. 

Literally the least fun I've had playing a game in many, many years. Tedious, pointless, futile. It is the myth of Sisyphus as a game mode. Horrible.
As with all Civ games this one is super addictive. Play at your own risk (to your sense of time). Enjoy!

Is it possible to try too many new things with a sequel? 

Civ V was a huge success, popular to this day. And Civ VI tries to re-invent those prodigious wheels with multiple tech-trees, wildly unique civilizations, intense city planning and oh-so-many mini-quests. A lot of it works, but I can't help thinking they changed so much, it's hard to tell which elements are worth keeping in the franchise long term. 

It's like an experiment with too many variables, but where the results are so fascinating you can't ignore them.

An incredible game, that inherits from his legacy and perfects it. The pure, simple graphics will prevent you from getting bored of the visuals while being nice, an essential for any long lasting game, and since civ6 is, contrary to his predecessors, supposed to be a very long lasting game, this point is very important. In game, the chosen mechanics are interesting, very well balanced and still relatively intuitive for newcomers, I must applause that as well. What I wanna criticize, are the gathering storm dlc, a bit weak and not so interesting to play, and the "heroes" dlc, that completely changes the early game in a game of pure luck, while also feeling a little out of place, with the rest of the game/franchise.
I could go on and on about how great this game is, how much I like how great the district system is, but that would be boring pretty quickly, so I will just resume to a simple comment and a note:
Overall great game, I recommend new players to try it and learn it (I know strategy games can be rough at start, just persevere a little bit!) (Also if you can, take the loyalty dlc, it's great!)

I decided to play test the widely popular Civilization 6 game just now. I gave it an honest effort and went in with a neutral attitude and an open mind. It is a complete disaster IMO. It falls right into the mold of other 4X TBS games. The UI, the AI, the mindless repetitive clicking, the hidden information that is hard to find, the useless information being imposed on the player that cannot be turned off, the bugs, the many arbitrary and surprising complex stupid rules, the extensive required reading, the annoying boring music, the long load times, compatibility problems with my computer, the surprising results of user actions, the nonsense requirements to play that game well, the repeat and long chain of user actions needed to do a simple thing, the lack of challenge, etc.

Great sequel

A great game, still unreachable in its genre and I highly doubt Civ 7 will be the same revolution as the sixth one. It's a monumental representative of 4X strategies, however, there are a couple of flaws as well: 

- Extremely poor energy management system. It could be made much better, for example, with the cell upgrades going to the districts and setting the limited power output for a plant. However, we still have a "power range" one which restricts the planning variations and is simply uncomfortable. 
- Environmental impact is way too strong. I mean ok, there can be a few plants around the area, however, how on Earth would they make the whole coastal line drown? That's simply nonsense and it turns the game into a nightmare closer to the 300th turn, especially if you're focusing on mass-production strategy.
- The imbalance is just striking. This point is valid for the multiplayer mostly, but is a problem at higher levels of difficulty as well. 
- Barbarian issue. I understand that those are barbarians, the rejects, however, giving 1XP only for confronting those is way too illogical. The warriors are fighting just the same way as with the other civilizations, where's justice? :D But jokes aside, this has to be revamped, since barbarians are becoming the source of frustration and can be a worse problem than an aggressive neighbour, still the output from defeating them is just minimal. 

Still, those are all the flaws I could remember so far. And now, let's check the overall situation: are there any 4X strategies that are as entertaining as Civ VI? Probably yes. However, is there anything better than this one in terms of quality and perfect mechanics? Hell no. And boy, are there dozens of mechanics to witness. 

This game is on top, the crown's still there (with Civ V sharing it 13 years after the release). So as soon as you're ready to jump in, do so. You will definitely not regret it.

This game is just... bad. It's really, really boring. There's almost nothing good about it. 

Civ 6 has the same primary issue as Civ 5, where they can't figure out how to actually make the AI smarter and just give the computer absurd bonuses to make it more likely you lose. They're erratic, irrational, and lack any sense of strategy. They don't analyze your victory conditions, then work against them. They just do things. Often, things that don't have any chance at achieving victory. They'll waste resources on a victory condition they have NO hope of achieving, rather than focusing on the one that might actually work. It's dreadful. 

What's worse, they actually made the game MORE frustrating to play than Civ 5. The district system and forced micromangement of both builders and military engineers to establish tile improvements slows gameplay to a crawl. Armies and Corps were a nice idea to make armies slightly less tedious in the mid/late-game, but you can almost entirely ignore the military aspect of the game beyond taking out barbarians. And, there are no barbarians by the time you can form Corps. 

After 100 hours, victories on every difficulty mode, and with a handful of different leaders/conditions, I can confidently say I don't like this game. It's not too difficult. I don't hate the genre. I liked Civ 5. Unfortunately, Civ 6 was a step backwards. 

If you want to play a good strategy game, go buy Civ 5. It's Civ 6, but better.

I had fallen in love with Civ 5. You could do crazy things like take Attila and get a cultural victory, or take Ghandi and get a Domination victory. I could win games on 5 of the difficulties. Here in Civ 6 it's completely unforgiving. I'm playing on the easiest 2 difficulties and I end up with the Defeat screen all the time. I've had 1 victory ever, playing as Korea and going for the Science victory. I feel like every turn you better be making your correct decision or from that point forward it's a downward spiral. If this is the future of Civ games, I won't be buying into them any more.

It's a real time eater, you will always want to know what happens next. The first two hours are a race against other nations to progress your civilization's technology and religion and land mass. Then you might go to war to get more or make deals to diplomatically gain what you want, you might even team up with another civilization and crush the others. The range is wide and always that strategic kind of fun. The worst part might be waiting for turns but you can set this to be faster, I wish I knew earlier than after playing for 12 hours total. Walking on eggshells when it comes to pleasing all the other world leaders can be a pain too when you want to play freely and keep on good terms with them. Some more AI would be really interesting, as a person who plays to conquer areas, it would be cool to see some weaker Civilizations want to join you for your success rather than denounce you regardless. More personality then, I guess. Otherwise, the game is really smart and networked beautifully, and the game style is timeless.

02/10 "CIV 5" Simulator 2016

As a fan of strategy games I really wanted to like civilization. I played civ5 a bit a long time ago but this game is my first introduction to the series, and it's just very mediocre. The price is absurd as well (I get that you spent a lot of money on detailed 3d models that you can't even zoom into, but come on, it wasn't needed). Luckily it goes on big sales. 

[b]Civilizations are same-y.[/b] You get a unit that can boost your military during an age, bonuses that make you stronger during certain ages and bonuses that generally help you achieve a certain victory. That's all. And for whatever reason it's supposed to be a selling point of the Civilization 6 game.

[b]The victory conditions don't interact with each other.[/b] You always have to max-out one thing (science, faith, culture, money/production) and use it to achieve goals. The four victories are very disjointed from one another. Playing science you care only about science and production, playing culture you care only about culture and maybe some faith, playing military is just like playing science cause you need better weapons and production to build them, playing faith is somewhat fun cause you need to build infrastructure for delivering missionaries to different places quick, but the AI just has no chance.

[b]The AI is braindead. Diplomacy is stupid.[/b] I played the game on King difficulty which I heard is the "balanced" one. But the problem doesn't lie in the difficulty, just in how the AI behaves. It seems to target a certain victory, but is incredibly slow. I won 3 games and haven't seen the AI get over 50% to victory. The AI also allows you to walk all over it thanks to diplomacy. Usually the world is split in two blocks that fight one another but if you aren't the civ with the least amount of arms no one will target you. The AI will also do absolutely nothing to stop you from ever reaching victory. **This isn't a historical game, but the AI behaves "realistically".** Playing against players they'd attack you to stop you from winning even if they don't have a chance. Here, the AI just sits around and maaaybee manages to capture like 5 cities in the first 200 turns from some other AI.

[b]For a strategy game, there's very little strategy.[/b] Sure, you follow some builds, like "here I will take +2 culture in each culture district and then build culture district and also get a religion that gives me +1 culture per district". But it feels like some simple puzzle. People call this game chess, I call it "match-three-gems-in-a-row" mobile type of game. The strategy could happen in war or faith combat *if only the AI was actually playing the game* actively. The most strategy is probs in choosing the right government bonuses for the time and researching the right tech, but this is like 5% of the final gameplay.

[b]Game can't choose if it's a historical simulator or a strategy.[/b] As I said, the AI behaves as if it was real life (except for "this is a game" sort of silliness). Their leaders also have some agendas you need to fulfill to have good relations with them which are usually super random. Tech tree and culture trees are realistic. But civs and leaders make no sense. Your king/queen is immortal, Ancient Greek free cities can beat victorian England and exist in the same period. Peter the Great leads an army of cavemen. Modern cities can be protected by bows.
I say the game should just abandon all realism and turn into a puzzle strategy. 

With all that said, game isn't the worst. You kinda loll about around the AI, get big numbers and win. It looks good, the UI is good, music is cool, graphical designs of civ leaders are cool, narrator guy is cool. The features are also there. The culture and science tech trees are very nicely balanced and introduce cool new features along with time. Too bad that these features don't interact in any meaningful way and the AI barely plays the game.
I'm fell in love with this game, i recommend this game a lot, but be careful about getting addicted.

I am writing a negative review not because this game isn't good. It is. It's incredibly good but because at least for me this  game is honestly lacking compared to earlier titles. While this game improves on most aspects from earlier titles, such as city improvements, animations, resources, unit controls etc what infuriates me is that it's a massive step back in the diplomacy and war department. The ai does not want to fight wars. Ever. Like they simply do not happen. To my knowledge, I have had exactly one game where the ai declared war on me. In every other game, it was I who was the war monger while the other nations sat around passively. I don't need an army other then to deal with barbarians. In general you can fully ignore diplomacy, and millitary and just focus on peaceful deving. There is no satisfaction in dealing with other nations because there is no threat, no nothing. At the 5th level of difficulty at this game it's still a snooze fest and I could honestly leave all my cities undefended and be fine. Compare this to Civ 3. At the 5th level of difficulty you are playing the game of thrones. There are AIs which are naturally agressive and will declare war on you if you don't give them gifts, if they think you to weak or occassionally simply because. When they attack they will come not with 1 unit, not with 2 but 20, 30, 40.  You have to be on your toes, you have to do diplomacy because if you don't the AI will team up against you and crush you. It's thrilling. You are constantly walking this tight rope of balancing millitary production, city improvement. The ai will have resources, tech, money, luxuries which you need and all the time you are asking yourself what can I afford to give, what can I afford to trade which will long term keep me in the lead. Wars can be fought often and it won't ruin your relations long term. This is why I am giving this game a negative review. I play this game for the game of thrones style politics while guiding a nation into the future long term and I am annoyed that both civ 3 and 4 games which are over a decade old have these features but this one doesnt.
