The tutorial is badly inadequate, even coming from previous Civ games. Playing single player provides further guidance, but this is not indicated anywhere in the game prior to launching the single player mode, and the game has a built-in Civilopedia which you can refer to to fill in the rest of your knowledge, but it's difficult to navigate and very incomplete. Utterly inadequate on all fronts.

Multiplayer is without a doubt the worst of any Civ game. Visual glitches abound where one or more players see thing (including important thing like cities) in the wrong places. The non-host players will crash or freeze, and the higher the ping the worse it gets. Helpfully, the game overrides Alt+F4 (close application) so you have to open task manager to close if it's frozen. The non-host players will also get periodically desynced, meaning they get a loading screen and the host player gets a notification. If a player crashes the game will immediately give their turn to the AI, who plays inexcusably poorly. 

Compounding this, even the single player game is loaded with bugs. Even something as simple as automatically advancing between units for orders routinely fails, either moving the camera to a unit other than the one being controlled, moving to a unit who is already moving like you gave them orders, or ignoring that some units need orders. This is an absolutely core game mechanic and it's completely broken. Everything built on top of it is also completely broken, but even if this was the only problem the game is still a failure as a Civilization game, and the fact that the game is frustratingly unclear on how things are *supposed* to work or what any given mechanic *actually means* results in situations where it's impossible to tell if something is working as intended and simply hard to figure out, or if it's a broken mechanic that doesn't work correctly most of the time (spoiler alert it's absolutely the second one in every single case).

On top of what is mechanically wrong with the game, the leader character models are hideous and you are forced to interact with them for any diplomacy options. They look like Bratz dolls. Even the DLC character who look somewhat more humanoid just look like newer Bratz dolls. To make that entire system worse and more frustrating, the characters have few lines and as such never actually specify why they're upset. Rip them all out and the game will be better. They're absolutely horrifying. Why is diplomacy a full-screen thing, also? Why does it not prevent me from interacting with the word *through* the screen? Wouldn't it be better in every way for it to be a popup? You guys got this right as far back as Civ: Call To Power, which was nearly 3 decades ago, why mess it up now?

Overall just a shitty, shitty hit for those of us (myself included) who are hopelessly addicted to Civ. If this is your first time, there would be no worse entry point for the series in the past 30 years.

Civilization 6 still stands as the ultimate digital board game for history nuts where the board --the world-- is the soul of every challenge and opportunity. 

In Civ, you build an empire that vies to stand the test of time while competing with other civilizations for a set of victory conditions, be it peaceful or warmongering. But you're also playing with, for, and against the generated map where forests, deserts and resource-rich tundras influence how your civilization flows. 

This challenging dynamic does come with a learning curve to overcome, but much of what you need to be to be victorious isn't necessary when you start exploring. You will settle cities and develop the tiles in your empire, you will train a formidable military force and wage turn-based warfare while also conducting diplomacy. Six game winning objectives exist that rewards both military focused players and players who prefer peace. Plenty of in-game hints help ease new players while also offering course-correction for when things don't go your way .

The need for foresight is unending. There is no obviously 'correct' way to improve your empire. There are always sacrifices to make, like when I fell behind in science due to lacking eligible tiles but clutched the game through the diplomatic objective. It's a fantastic, richly realized way of forcing difficult decisions at every bend in the river where no two cities are the same. The Civ staples of war and diplomacy have been honed to the sharpest edge in the franchise. AI leaders are now given agendas (one which is public and the other being uncovered through espionage, relationship building or context observation) that overtly tell you what they like and don't like and make it possible to stay on everyone's good side if you're willing to. 

This is definitely a thinking mans game which is fantastic in multiplayer with like minded players. Matches can sometimes take a week to finish if you're playing with your friends 3 hours a day, but usually the endgame can be reached in 20 total hours. Which isn't bad at all due to the addictive nature of this 4x game.

What can I say?  Either you know Civilization or you are probably new to strategy games and 4X in particular (explore, expand, exploit, exterminate).  Civ has been called the "ultimate digital board game", and with good reason.  Civ VI is the most technically and graphically advanced entry in the franchise (so far, with Civ VII on the horizon), and is a sprawling, deep game but surprisingly accessible, which is often not the case with grand strategy games.  It will take you a long time to run out of things in the base game, much longer with the DLCs, and then there's a strong modding community, which will let you try anything from simple UI tweaks to the completely ridiculous.  I feel like I still haven't run out of things to do (let alone the literally hundreds of achievements to unlock).

The only people I would not recommend play this is anyone with poor impulse control, as the franchise that invented the phrase "Just one more turn..." can indeed be a huge time sink.  Otherwise, if you enjoy strategy games, Civ VI is the modern standard by which other turn-based games are measured (not that it's necessarily the best, as that's deeply subjective, but if you're a fan of the genre, it's a must-play).  It manages to include a lot of historical richness while still adding its own character and flavour.

The DLCs added a lot to the game, including diving into fantasy, which is unusual for Civilization.  You can fight zombies or include vampires and mythical heroes, or try and survive an apocalypse.  "Gathering Storm" in particular is an excellent addition, if in most game modes its model of the climate crisis doesn't end up really affecting much.

If you watch for specials, you can now pick up the whole package for cheap, which will mean it's more than worth it for time you'll get out of it, though even at full price, if you're a strategy gamer you'll potentially be able to enjoy hundreds of hours.

Not bad. It's not necessarily an improvement over civ 5, it is different than civ 5 and does some things better, some things worse.

Here are some of the main new mechanics and my opinion on them:

Districts: You place these on tiles and they make up most of the buildings you can make in a city. There are two main consequences of this new system. One, it requires significantly more time and effort to play the game in an optimal way since which tiles you place your districts on is very important. While I like this in single player, it makes multiplayer more tedious. Two, it kills "tall" builds in a pretty extreme manner. While some people complained civ 5 took its pro-tall approach a bit far, the districts system completely kills tall builds because districts simply have more yields than tiles and they are limited by the number of cities you have. It is also advantageous to place cities close enough to make their districts close to each other for adjacency bonuses. There is also no penalty to making more cities other than settlers getting more expensive as you build more settlers. So there is really only one way to play this game and it's spamming as many cities as possible as close as possible.

Civics: Culture is now like a second type of science. Your culture yields allow you to advance in your civics tree similar to how you use science yields to advance in the science tree. I like this mechanic. It adds more depth to the strategy without being boring or tedious. Civics can be just as important as techs depending on what you are going for so this makes low-science high-culture builds possible, even in multiplayer. You'll still want to catch up in science at some point but prioritizing culture over science is a valid strategy. Overall, pretty good mechanic.

Policies: These are kind of part of the new civics system but also a separate mechanic. Civics unlock policies and government types and you can run a certain number of policies based on your government type. This mechanic can feel a bit overwhelming and tedious at first but after a few hundred hours of play, I started liking this mechanic too. It is also something that adds strategic depth to the game.

Loyalty: This is essentially a mechanic they invented to stop extreme forward settling and I really like the idea, although there are some issues with implementation. The population of your cities emanate an aura of loyalty to your civilization and if you settle a city far away from your civilization and close to an enemy civilization who has a lot of high-pop cities nearby, that city will flip to the enemy civ. While this mostly works well, it can feel really dumb on congested starts on deity difficulty where your capital can start losing loyalty already in the very first few turns. They probably should have made the capital have higher defensive pressure or something along those lines.

Other than the new mechanics, compared to civ 5, I think the new art style is significantly worse and in addition, they seem to have followed "diversity" quotas when choosing the leaders. There are some female leaders who weren't of any real historical relevance.

The soundtrack is great. It might even be better than the civ 5 soundtrack.

Overall, it's a decent game which has some advantages and disadvantages compared to civ 5. It's probably worth a try, especially on sale.

Overall Score: 7/10

Finally tried this game after buying it and avoiding it for quite a few years in fear of being disappointed after Civ V elevated series near perfection. Unfortunately my fears were true. Please note this review is written from a point of view of long term fan of the series, but I belive most annoying parts of the game do not require experience of previous games to still be quite painful to play around.

I'll start with positives,
Tech trees and new cards system seems to avoid the major problem of Civ V, where community quickly realized there really are only 2 effective playstyles, with minor variations in late game, depending on the victory you are going for. Ability to boost tech tree and culture forces player to play around their spawn location and while it relies heavy on random factors I still see it as good change, because you need to play with the cards you've been dealt.
In short you don't like games with strick META you will like this one more.

Redesign of combat promotions and support units eliminates previous unbalaned strategies that relied on leveling ranged units to get massive advantage on sieges. Now range for example can be boosted by support units and some naval units have increased range by default, making combat more balanced.

Religion is now a real mechanic that affects a game way more than some extra builings or great people currency, including new victory method.

If you have DLCs, Climate Change in Gathering Storm is great addon to play with, putting massive pressure in islands focused maps and lat game.

There are some questionable decisions like confusing resources system, balance of civilizations, way too many policy cards to comfortably juggle in late game, but I see these more as very confusing at first and kind of neutral if you play few games and learn by doing.

Now the biggest crime of this game that does not let me give that title positive review, city districs system, which are extensions of your city that occupy a map tile like you city does, unlocking  for that city building of its category, for example, workshop is now in industrial district, shrine in religious, etc. These tiles are more, or less effective depending on the tiles adjacent to it, there are also special districts that can't be placed only on compatible tiles, like aqueduct or canal.
This makes min-maxing your districts not always possible depending on your city placements, depending on free tiles, rivers etc. 
That little RNG element is not bad in itself, it just forces player to spend a little too much time planning perfect placement for all the districts they want to build before settling in new location, confusing at first, but becomes easier when you memorize all the tiles and bonuses.
There is one thing that makes this new mechanic go from aditional chore to infuriating RNG hell. You can't build on strategic and luxurious resources. You have perfect spawn for your first city but there is one tile of chocolate ina way? You need to give up at least one district or wonder or both. Is it blocking you from build a canal? Too bad, you need to move or give up naval play. I want to say it decides who possibly wins a game at turn 1, but it is even worse. Strategic resources like iron still are visible only after researching it in tech tree. That means, even if you have the perfect spot that can fit all the buildings you want to fit in the city, you still can be screwed over by the game, when strategic resource shows up on random tile 10, 30, or 50 turns later, and there is NOTHING you can do to play around it or prevent it. 
Awful game design that makes multiplayer games massively unbalanced, and if you want to beat the game on divine, enjoy wasting your time reseting, because now spawning next to a resource is a bad thing.

INB4: I know there are mods to let you erase all resources, but it is not official. If I want to beat a game with mods I can just install wim button. Devs team decided to ruin player experience by one simple mechanic and I respect their decision to make your game unwinnable if the stars do not allign

For those who have played Civ4, Vanilla Civ6  will be a disappointment for those who like to play a domination game.  It's because the AI aggressiveness and diplomacy has been nerfed in the extreme from Civ4,  The AI leaders will denounce you at the drop of a hat for the sole reason they don't like you.  They will declare war on you, then not attack you, and when you are about to take one of their cities will sue for peace,  If you take the city anyway, all the other civs will accuse you of being a war monger.   
Also, the AI simply does not build military units, especially in the late game.  On King difficulty, Japan only built two warriors any called it a day,  For those who like to play cultural, scientific or religious games Civ6 will be a challenge, because you really don't need to worry about being attacked by another aggressive civ with the same intensity as Civ4.    The issue I have with the game is that in  order to win cultural or scientific games at the higher levels you will be sorely tempted to declare war and pillage the scientific and cultural districts of your opponents.  Districts which the AI fails to protect.    However, if you purchase Civ6 Athology and get the Rise ad Fall and Gathering Storm DLC,  the AI is much improved.  Loyalty for cities like Civ4 and the added Diplomancy victory makes the game much more of a challenge and much more in interesting.

First time writing a negative review for a game and well, this game is rather something.

I'm gonna get straight to the point, Civilization is an amazing franchise, however, a sequel game hasn't made me this disappointed than the time I went to see Amy Schumer doing stand-up.
I have many notable issues while the playing the game that just straight up made me go "why" or "tf?" CIV VI attempts to add on in many ways to the franchise but by far fails miserably, while playing this I struggled to even get through one hour of gameplay before giving up (I had it on double time or Online turn cycle.)

CIV VI removes many notable features I've come to love, even the simplistic of ones, and tries to innovate but somehow making the game comparable to that of rocket science for a lifelong player (maybe I'm just braindead?) To be honest, I shouldn't have to feel the need to install a mod to acquire a feature that should've been in the game in the first place.

Here's my 95 theses with Firaxis Games:
Want to Automate builders, and scouts? - NOPE
Want to build Wonders all in your strongest city? - NOPE
Want to keep all of your tiles productive? (Build on all tiles?) - NOPE 
[Wonders now consume tiles, Districts that were once buildings in CIV V consume tiles, Workers only last for 3 tiles)
Want to play peacefully or build tall? - NOPE (Outpaced by AI + the system favors War + Inflation system.)

Whats the Inflation system you may ask? In the previous game, you would build more and more productive cities, with price for units, buildings, wonders, etc, never catching up. In this game, you are slammed with a crazy turn price if you want to build more things. 

Wonders are under-powered significantly in this game, almost feels as if you are being punished for building them in the first place, why waste my time with a wonder (that would've given you a significant bonus in CIV V) when I can just build so and so?

The UI is a confusing, disgusting, horrific mess. The Artwork is horrible, and I'm talking mainly about the characters, why are their eyes so big? Why does it feel like I am playing a Gameloft mobile game? None of them look realistic. 

World Congress? SAY LESS BECAUSE IT DOESN'T EXIST IN THIS GAME. (If you wanted it, you can't get it unless you cough up $40.00 for the DLC.) Not to mention when you did finally get there, it just constantly spammed notifications every turn, and was generally gnarly to look at.

Diplomacy? Practically non-existent. You would think the AI would be capable of actually working with you. Everyone just ends up making each other mad, because nobody can meet each other TOTALLY realistic expectations.

Adding a Dark Age system? Why the hell does it need to exist? Theres with no way to avoid it. It feels like they are just purposefully giving me testicular torsion for playing the game. 

Let's talk briefly about Policies... The Social Policies in CIV V don't exist in this game as a simple system. For some reason, culture just isn't a thing or has minimal impact, whereas you would typically purchase bonuses depending on how you want to play. In CIV VI they divide it into seemingly 3 different bonus boards that you have to keep track of? Some of which are free (Including a seemingly useless Governor system for each city and era theme bonus system.) The main being a Civic policy tree where you need to research policy cards to display the bonuses you want. Like okay, I see where they might think this is an improvement to help enhance how players may want to play, but seem to over complicate a system that was fine to begin with.

A simple note, why do we need to use a launcher for this game? Practically useless, crashes the game on start up, or won't load at all, they just steal your info on top of that. Literally they are spitting in your face like a drunk goth chick at a Dennys.

Honestly, to prevent this from just being a continuing wall of text I'm gonna spare you guys the rest, just don't bother trying to get into this one. They had good intentions I'm sure and they also had some cool ideas like a dynamic climate and landscaping system with a actually nice looking map that reacted to such events, but took it too far just over complicating things. Lesson to be learned here overall is that sometimes its okay not to change things, not everything needs to be different in a sequel title. Hopefully CIV VII will be something better than this, till then, Ill just return to V.

[h1] Just...
one...
more...
turn... (Still a masterpeice) [/h1] I only came to Civ V lately, as in this year. Iâ€™ve barely played a bit of the predecessors, just to get an idea of what I missed before the paragon that Civ V is graced my monitor. There are balancing issues yet with Civ VI. And the achievements need more challenge. 

16. Multiple full color map filters: Itâ€™s much more than just the lovely map art, & the view of a map before the world is uncovered. They improve decision making just like all the other menus in the game. Pins are added to mark the map for exploration.

15. Augmented GP Abilities: You can retire a GP, convert him to a collectible or unit upgrade, keep him around for passive boosts, or even pass on him altogether; saving your points for the next GP in the lineup. If you want a GP & are losing to another civ, you can throw some hard earned gold into the GP pool to steal him before they are able to recruit him.

14. Wider choice of Historical Great Persons: I loved having John the Baptist found my first religion. But, also you can view a gallery of all your collected art & relics anytime, which are also obtained as relics from religious martyrs, & found in villages.

13. Movement is more intuitive & the zone of control is more transparent. Where movement is slowed down from geographical features on the map, you quickly feel more boxed in at first. But, this feels more natural because you begin to live in your own civ, not really moving out to see the world until mid-game or later. This forces you to be more aware of your neighbors than it did when you branched out all over the map.

12. Escort Bindings & Unit Stacking: This is actually going back to Civ IV &, it definitely is a no-brainer. No reason why we shouldnâ€™t be able to bind a soldier to our settler & send him around the world. Being able to build armies & regiments takes the warfare to a new level, in terms of power on the front line in a small hex of space.

11. Promotion & naming of units: Lends a greater personal investment in â€œThe Great White Arrows,â€ when you know you are sending them to their death with 3 promotion levels down the drain. There is a randomization feature that is great for getting these crazy names, if you donâ€™t want to name them Jack or Fred.

10. Roads Simplified: They are laid automatically by traders. Yet, options are still present for making individual road segments with the engineers. Military engineers & builders are like specialists, compared to the workers from Civ V who did it all. The trade routes system is simpler to use, but you can NOT tell where you last sent specific routes. Of course this doesnâ€™t seem to be a problem, since itâ€™s easier to see at a glance & by popping out the right side tab where you already have routes currently.

9. Addition of short term projects in the construction queue, similar to the Civ V worldâ€™s fair for late game boosts. You can boost your bank account by investing in the Commercial Hub, or beef up production, Military, or Science at any time you need an edge in a certain direction. This gives the player more control over the outcome, & certainly allows for serious strategy.

8. Graphics are without perceptible flaws. This makes the game even more engaging... immersive! Wonders are bigger. Also, you can see the great works & trade them. Camera orientation during combat needs correction. It is necessary to edit game files to gain certain optional controls that should have been in- game, like spinning the map & stopping the infernal unit auto-advance. It does have the appearance that they werenâ€™t quite finished with this aspect of the game at release. The art & graphic changes add greatly to the experience. For example, you can hover over districts in other civs to spy out what great works are hidden in which buildings, if you are planning to steal some art.

7. The City/ States are color coded, providing bonuses for suzerain status, which is hard to maintain for any length of time, since there is much competition. Conquering a CS removes those resources & the protection buffer they provide from the other civs. You also have the ability to conscript their military. So, itâ€™s more to your benefit to keep the CS intact.

6. Espionage: You have a choice about whether or not to invest in training spies. You can choose what action they take; steal art, siphon money, sabotage production by burning buildings, etc. Or, you may use them as counterspies, protecting specific buildings & their adjacencies. Roleplay is enhanced by choices for escape when detected. If you capture an enemy spy, you may trade him back to the opponent, or not.

5. Developing a culture feels more like an integrated part of your civilization, rather than an optional sidetrack. Not only are the wonders showcased on individual tiles, but theyâ€™ve made the details more visible, like mine cars zipping around the track. The art & music become a part of the world around you, with increased abilities to place & move works physically.

4. The religious combat is great! Before, you had little options for dealing with those missionaries wondering into your civ, tearing apart the fabric of your culture. You couldnâ€™t attack them or remove them with a unit without a war dec. The inquisition is more realistic, & dying apostles leave behind relics, which can be placed in temples, or traded as valued great works or stolen. I did find it unfortunate that I canâ€™t rename my religion to a certain denominational name if I choose the Christianity symbol. You are able to choose a generic zodiac symbol & give it a name of choice, but that really is illogical. You should ideally be given more choices in personalization, not less than in Civ V.

3. Alliances are totally expanded, allowing you to form relationships on different levels. Itâ€™s possible to convince the AI to change its plan to attack. The AI is more responsive to diplomacy, behaves more rationally & gives you feedback on how you are meeting their agenda. You are given more options for holding the AI accountable, as in being able to denounce them, or make them pay for spying on you. Sometimes the option appears to ask them to remove their units from your borders. But, this is not yet consistent.

2. Combat: Increased barb difficulty has upped the challenge. Over time, they fade from the game as you begin to encounter other civs. I donâ€™t encounter pirates in international waters. A slider to increase the appearance of barbs would be great. Either way, the combat is definitely one of the best improvements in the game. More siege equipment is available. The improved landscape features allow for greater defensive power. Fighting is more visible & realistic looking.

1. The system of civic progress has been streamlined. Some are pulled from the Tech tree, the ideologies, & policies of Civ V. Taken together with the Tech tree, it adds a masterful touch to the gameplay & just makes more sense. With the system of card slotting & governments whichever you choose, you can reach the victory of your choice. This expansion gives more control over boosts, & allows you the chance to steamroll your game, if you are wise enough to â€œlead your people well.â€ Comments & questions are welcome.

Civilization VI is very fun, and I am still enjoying it after 200+ hours of playtime. I would generally give it a high-ish rating... 7/10. Here are the only things that I see as problems in the game that bring down the score: 1. Gathering Storm expansion has a built in climate change model that you can't turn off. You can turn down the natural disaster intensity, but natural disasters aren't the problem. I expect that there will be natural disasters, that is fine. What I DO NOT want is the way that they escalate over time into the late game, causing sea levels to rise and all of that other NONSENSE. Natural disasters would be a great addition to the game if not for the escalation over time feature. This forces you to play with the Rise and Fall expansion, which is missing other things that I enjoy being in the game, creating an experience that is not fully customizable and ultimately leaves the game wanting for features that were in previous Civ games. 2. In single player mode, you cannot make de facto team alliances in the game options screen with other AI players. It should be self evident why this is bad. This in combination with the game's juvenile AI thinking creates a situation in which there are no true alliances in the game, causing any ally to turn on you the moment you decide to take nearly any kind of war action, which is typically necessary to win the game, even if not going for domination victory. 3. The creators of Civilization VI have now and in the past typically avoided specific political leaders for political reasons, and I feel this damages the game, in addition to simply not including SOME leaders that should be a no brainer for entry into the game. Adolph Hitler, Joseph Stalin, Mao Zedong, Pol Pot, Vladimir Lenin, Emperor Hirohito, and so forth aren't in the game for what appear to be obvious political reasons. Other leaders that you would think would be in the game but aren't are George Washington, Napoleon Bonaparte, and any one of a number of European monarchs that would certainly be more fun to play with and against than the ones that they have placed in the game. This is a game about history, yet they specifically choose to pick out "leaders" that were fairly historically insignificant to represent countries that had, quite frankly, much stronger leaders across history. Yet they are unavailable for play. And certainly, I'm not against the addition of MORE leaders rather than less, but Firaxis/Aspyr are asking for quite a bit of money for all of these expansion packs and yet none of the aforementioned leaders are included in them. Instead, what do we get? A whole bunch of stinkers that no one wants or cares about. It's a problem. Gameplay is solid, content and features are lacking in some places. Could be better, but overall: 7/10.

By far the worst Civ game and possibly the worst strategy game released by a professional studio. The games appearance and UI are unrefined and simplified, giving the whole game an armature and almost juvenile feel. The diplomacy in this game is completely  non existent.  Each ai has a list of things that give them severe opinion  penalties. Not only is this annoying for the player; I mean who wants to be denounced simply for having one less ship than Norway, but it also  ensures that the ai all hate eachother. Gone are the war pacts from previous civ games. Roosevelt is too busy denouncing someone for being on a different continent while Victoria is too busy denouncing them for being on her continent. In total, you'd think they'd have this formula figured out by now,  but no, they don't. They attempted to "modernize" the experience and threw out a large majority of beloved features in the process. They simultaneously over complicated some features such as city management whilst also simplifying numerous others. At least other Civ games improved as time went on, but their solution to these problems was to further complicate things. Do you like colonizing and conquering, here have an inane loyalty system that only makes sense 10% of the time  and that the ai can't manage at all. You like coastal cities, well make sure to kill every civ before the industrial era or your cities may just end up underwater by the 1800's. In total, this entire game is one massive case of cool concept, terrible execution. Do yourself a favor and purchase one of the previous civ games.

Never and I mean NEVER did I think my opinion of this game would only get worse with time. I can definitively say that this is one of my least favorite games from a reputable developer of all times at this point. With EVERY dlc, the ai has gotten worse and worse, to the point of being almost nonfunctional. The ai refuses to settle more than a few cities unless you play on higher difficulties, and even on higher difficulties, it's pathetically inept. If you survive the initial warrior spam on deity, then you are very unlikely to face any challenge for the rest of the playthrough with a few exceptions up until the race for victory. The new leaders are horrible and are in some cases literal reskins of existing leaders. How about you give us actual content Firaxis instead of sticking Teddy in a cowboy hat and giving yourselves a pat on the back. This game has single handily turned me against this series and I have no hope for the future. Civ V barely functions on modern hardware so it's incredibly frustrating to play now, and this game is just a steaming turd.

One of the best strategic games what you can find: It is well designed, plenty of different play-styles, so many nationalities, ..., although it has one downside: games (even in the quickest speed) can take up to hours or days to finish it with your friends. Against AI it is also challenging and fun and you will be able to pause the match whenever you want to. 

I would say it can easily take up to 10+ hours to get familiar with the game and with the mechanics, if you will not burn out on the way, then you will enjoy your new Civilization.

"Civilization IV"ğŸ’“â¤ is not just a game; it's a profound journey through the annals of human history that tugs at your heartstrings. As you build your civilization from the ground up, you embark on an emotional rollercoaster of triumphs and tribulations.

The sheer grandeur of "Civilization IV" is awe-inspiring. Every turn feels like a canvas on which you paint the story of your people, your culture, and your legacy. From the very first city, you nurture it like a parent watching a child grow. The emotional connection to your virtual world is undeniable.

The diplomacy, alliances, and betrayals evoke feelings of trust and betrayalğŸ’”, while the thrill of technological discoveries resonates deeply. When you complete the journey to victory, whether through culture, science, or conquest, there's an indescribable sense of accomplishment that brings a tear to your eye.

The hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, composed by Christopher Tin with the iconic "Baba Yetu," the theme song, adds layers of emotion to the gameplay, turning it into a truly transcendent experience. It's a musical masterpiece that elevates "Civilization IV" to an emotional symphony.

But what truly sets "Civilization IV" apart is how it reflects the triumphs and struggles of real-world civilizations. You feel the weight of history and the responsibility of leadership. You learn about the consequences of your decisions, both good and bad, which can lead to poignant moments of reflection.

In the end, "Civilization IV" isn't just a game; it's a testament to the human spirit, an emotional odyssey that takes you through the rise and fall of civilizations. It reminds us that history is more than facts and dates; it's a tapestry of emotions, and "Civilization IV" lets you weave your own thread into that rich fabric of time. It's not just a game; it's a masterpiece of human storytelling and connection.
